column2: China
column3: the US and the EU had to have unanimous support for the decision. Loading ...";english;2016-10-28T18:02:37.152+03:00;presstv.ir;FR;18495.0;Massive marine park declared in Antarctic Ocean;0.0;http://media.presstv.com/photo/20161028/fb09c4ef-0fe8-4ab7-a110-a96febedb3e7.jpg;0;0;0;0;0;state

column1: 7596;f59b74781b09931447034b591554e342c0b0e631;0;;2016-10-28T18:02:37.902+03:00;Comprehensive international resolve key to terror fight: Iran FM;"Politics Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif attends a news conference after a meeting with his counterparts Walid al-Muallem from Syria and Sergei Lavrov from Russia in Moscow
column2: Russia
column3: on October 28
column4: 2016. (Photo by Reuters)

column1: Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif says comprehensive international determination is necessary to fight and uproot terrorism in the Middle East.
The Iranian foreign minister made the remarks at the end of a three-way meeting among him and his Russian and Syrian counterparts
column2: Sergei Lavrov and Walid al-Muallem respectively
column3: in Moscow on Friday on the latest situation in Syria.

column1: Zarif said Tehran
column2: Moscow and Damascus should reinforce their cooperation in the campaign against terrorism.

column1: He stressed the importance of adopting strategies to stop the delivery of weapons and military equipment to the foreign-backed Takfiri militants wreaking havoc in Syria.
“The political settlement of the crisis in Syria will be possible through negotiations between the sides in order to put an end to this crisis
column2: ” Zarif said.

column1: The three foreign ministers agreed to intensify the fight against terrorism and said their countries have a common stance on the anti-terror campaign in the region
column2: particularly in Syria.

column1: Lavrov said Iran
column2: Russia and Syria have determined necessary frameworks for fighting terrorism and expressed their readiness to take measures that will play a key role in the campaign against the malicious phenomenon.

column1: The Russian foreign minister added that the Moscow meeting highlighted the significance of a firm and efficient battle against terrorism in the Middle East
column2: particularly in Syria.

column1: He said the meeting’s participants also discussed ways to send humanitarian aid to civilians in Syria and stop the flow of weapons into the hands of terrorists operating in the war-hit country.
Muallem
column2: for his part
column3: said the US is making no effort to find a political solution to the Syrian crisis.

column1: The Syrian foreign minister added that a recent agreement between Washington and Moscow
column2: signed in the Swiss city of Geneva in September
column3: failed to bear any fruit.

column1: After marathon talks in Geneva
column2: US Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart reached an agreement on September 10 to impose a ceasefire in the Syrian city of Aleppo and to coordinate military operations against terrorist groups in the country.

column1: Aleppo
column2: Syria’s second largest city
column3: remains divided between government forces in the west and foreign-backed terrorists in the east
column4: making it a frontline battleground.

column1: Russia
column2: which has been conducting an aerial military campaign against extremist militants in Syria
column3: has repeatedly voiced its readiness for a ceasefire. Russia has been insisting
column4: however
column5: that any such lull in fighting should be accompanied with a meticulous separation of terrorists from less extremist militants fighting against the Syrian government.

column1: The Syrian foreign minister said Washington is not interested in solving the crisis in Damascus and takes measures only to serve the its own interests and those of its regional allies.
Since March 2011
column2: Syria has been hit by militancy it blames on some Western states and their regional allies. Backed by the Russian air cover
column3: the Syrian military is engaged in an operation to rid the country of Daesh and other terrorist groups.

column1: The so-called Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and United Nations Special Envoy for Syria Staffan de Mistura have put the death toll from the Syria conflict at more than 300
column4: respectively.

column1: This is while the UN has stopped its official casualty count in Syria
column2: citing its inability to verify the figures it receives from various sources.

column1: Over the past few weeks
column2: the Syrian forces have wrested control of several areas across the war-torn country as they press ahead with their counter-terrorism operations.

column1: Iran
column2: Russia share strong anti-terror stance: Zarif

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in a meeting with his Russian counterpart earlier on Friday
column3: the Iranian foreign minister said Tehran and Moscow have “tough stances in the fight against terrorism in the region through common strategies.”

column1: “Tehran and Moscow have broad cooperation on regional issues such as the campaign against terrorism and extremism and we share views [on these matters]
column2: ” Zarif added. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov (R) speaks with his Iranian counterpart Mohammad Javad Zarif during a meeting in Moscow
column3: Russia
column4: on October 28
column5: 2016. (Photo by Reuters)

column1: He also noted that Iran and Russia have succeeded in making considerable progress in all fields including in economic and political sectors as well as regional and international developments.
I am pleased that in recent years relations between the Islamic Republic of Iran and the Russian Federation
column2: as two good neighbors and two key players
column3: have made many positive developments
column4: ” Zarif said.

column1: Lavrov
column2: for his part
column3: said Tehran and Moscow urged cooperation on an unrelenting approach to terrorists operating against the Syrian government.

column1: Iran and Russia have similar stances on the ongoing deadly crisis in Syria. Moscow and Tehran reject any foreign interference in the affairs of the war-hit country
column2: stressing that only the Syrians are entitled to decide their own fate.

column1: Iran has been providing military advisory assistance to the Syrian government in its campaign against terrorism. column1: US Republican vice presidential candidate Mike Pence says the mainstream media is biased against Donald Trump
column2: and there are “many instances” of voter fraud in the run up to the November 8 election.

column1: Republican presidential nominee Trump has recently intensified his criticism of the American electoral system. He calls the election process rigged
column2: and says the media is colluding with Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton in order to win the White House.

column1: He has questioned the legitimacy of the US elections
column2: saying that he believed the vote was already being ""rigged"" at many polling places.

column1: During his final presidential debate with Clinton last week
column2: Trump declared that he might not accept the results of the November 8 presidential election if there is evidence it was rigged.

column1: In an interview with CBS News on Friday
column2: Trump’s running mate
column3: Pence
column4: said
column5: “Make no mistake about it
column6: there are many instances in our lifetimes of voter fraud in individual polling places and in certain jurisdictions.”

column1: “Donald Trump and I are just calling on people to respectfully participate in the electoral process. We want a victory on Election Day
column2: but we also want it to be a victory for American democracy
column3: ” he stated. Donald Trump speaks at an event on October 15

column5: New Hampshire. (Photo by AFP)

column1: The governor of Indiana rejected claims of critics that Trump’s “rigging” rhetoric may encourage violence by his supporters if he loses the presidential election.
“We certainly would denounce any calls for anything other people being vigorously involved in the electoral process
column2: ” he said.

column1: “I have to tell you
column2: I really don’t see it. The people that rallying around our team
column3: rallying around our cause
column4: love this country
column5: are passionate about this country and are anxious to see change
column6: ” the GOP vice presidential nominee stated.

column1: He went on to accuse the media of unfairly backing Clinton.

“The level of negative coverage about my running mate in many quarters in the national media has just been overwhelming compared to any negative coverage or frankly the avalanche of scandals coming out of Hillary Clinton’s years as secretary of State
column2: ” Pence said. Attendees stand during the National Anthem at a rally for Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump at Cross Insurance Center on October 15
column3: 2016 in Bangor
column4: Maine. (Photo by AFP)

column1: According to a recent poll released
column2: 41 percent of American voters are saying the 2016 election could be ""stolen"" from Trump due to widespread voter fraud.

column1: And 73 percent of Republican voters think the election could be stolen from the billionaire businessman
column2: while 17 percent of Democrats agree with the prospect of rigging.

column1: American writer and political commentator Stephen Lendman told Press TV on October 17 Washington has been rigging elections for nearly 200 years in order to keep anti-establishment candidates away from the White House. column4: 2016. (Photo by AFP)

column1: Five Filipino fishermen who were released after being held hostage by Somali pirates for nearly five years have reunited with their families.
The seafarers arrived at the airport in the Philippine capital Manila on Friday.
I am so happy. This is what I had been praying for every night
column2: said Arnel Balbero
column4: as he was embraced by his four siblings at the airport.

column1: Just to be with my family
column2: even if we have nothing
column3: even if we have only little to eat
column4: I am already happy
column5: he said.

column1: His sister
column2: Lilia
column3: trembled at the sight of her brother. ""It's like a miracle. We never lost hope he would be freed
column4: she said.

column1: The Filipinos were among 26 freed hostages from Cambodia
column2: China
column3: Taiwan
column4: Indonesia and Vietnam who were freed on October 22. The 26 hostages plus three others made up the crew of Naham 3
column5: which was seized south of the Seychelles in March 2012.

column1: The captain of their Omani-flagged but Taiwanese-owned vessel died during the hijacking and two other crew members succumbed to illness in captivity.
Recounting memories
Balbero's cousin and fellow ex-hostage
column2: Elmer
column3: said the Somali pirates had cared little about the health of their captives.

column1: We asked the pirates for medicine but they did not give us any. Instead they said
column2: 'Where is your money?'"" said Elmer.

column1: The captives also said they suffered beatings at the hands of the pirates.
In our first week
column2: they called it our introduction. They used bamboo to beat us
column3: Arnel said.

column1: To survive
column2: the Filipinos did chores for their captors
column3: washing their clothes and even their weapons.

column1: We took it as a chance to also wash. We couldn't take a bath often because they only gave us a liter of water each day
column2: Arnel said.

column1: Hugging his two teenage daughters
column2: Elmer said it was thoughts of seeing his family again that kept him going during his captivity.

column1: Taiwan's Foreign Ministry said the men were freed after a ransom was paid by the ship's owner as well as groups contracted to negotiate with the pirates
column2: Taiwanese media reported.

column1: John Steed
column2: who works with the Hostage Support Partnership
column3: said the local community and tribal elders were involved in the ""difficult situation.""

column1: These are poor fishermen. The ship had no value
column2: they had no insurance
column3: and of course governments don't want to be involved in these sort of negotiations either
column4: he said. Sailors who had been held hostage by pirates for more than four years stand for a group photograph as they prepare to board an airplane after being released in Galkayo
column5: Somalia
column6: October 23
column7: 2016. (Photo by AP)

column1: The sailors are believed to be among the last remaining captives seized by Somali pirates during the surge in hostage-taking in the mid-2000s.

Piracy off the coast of Somalia has reduced significantly in recent years due to stronger international naval presence. column1: A new report has revealed that the number of Palestinian homes demolished by Israeli authorities in the largest division of the occupied West Bank since the beginning of the current year stands at more than 700.
Israel's Hebrew-language Haaretz newspaper reported on Friday that a total of 780 Palestinian homes have been demolished in Area C of the West Bank
column2: which constitutes about 61 percent of the territory and is under full Israeli military control
column3: since January
column4: leaving 1
column5: 129 people homeless.

column1: That compares to 453 demolitions in the area last year
column2: which left 580 Palestinians without any place of residence.

column1: The newspaper noted that a total of 125 Palestinian homes have also been destroyed in East Jerusalem al-Quds since the start of the year
column2: up from 78 last year.

column1: The demolitions affected 164 Palestinians in the region
column2: marking an increase from 108 the previous year.

column1: The revelations came only two days after Israeli military forces razed three Palestinian homes in the Beit Hanina and Silwan neighborhoods of East Jerusalem al-Quds
column2: displacing at least 44 people
column3: including minors.

column1: International bodies and rights groups argue that Israel’s sustained demolitions of Palestinian homes and structures in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem al-Quds are an attempt by the Tel Aviv regime to uproot Palestinians from their native territories
column2: and confiscate more land for expansion of illegal settlements.

column1: More than half a million Israelis live in over 230 illegal settlements built since the 1967 Israeli occupation of the Palestinian territories of the West Bank and East Jerusalem al-Quds.
The presence and continued expansion of Israeli settlements in occupied Palestinian lands have created a major obstacle for the efforts to establish peace in the Middle East.
The Palestinian Authority wants the West Bank as part of a future independent Palestinians state

column1: 7603;9d78165ad14032a7ca4e9f4befd9478d28580b68;0;;2016-10-28T18:02:46.567+03:00;Iran to resume gas exports to Turkey soon;"Iran to resume gas exports to Turkey soon Fri Oct 28
column2: 2016 12:10PM Energy Iran says it will resume exports of natural gas to Turkey by Monday after an explosion in the Turkish territory halted the supplies on Thursday night.

column1: Iran says its exports of natural gas to Turkey that have been halted reportedly as a result of an explosion inside the Turkish territory will resume within the next few days.
Sadeq Akbarpour
column2: the head of Gas Exports Measurement Facilities at Iran-Turkey Border
column3: told the domestic media that the required coordination is being carried out with the Turkish Botas company to resume Iran’s exports by next Monday.

column1: Akbarpour emphasized that Iran is ready to supply Turkey with its required gas whenever it voices its readiness.
Majid Bojarzadeh
column2: the spokesman of the National Iranian Gas Company (NIGC)
column3: also told Iran’s Shana news agency that Ankara had informed Tehran of a problem in the pipeline that carried Iranian gas into Turkey on Thursday night.

column1: Furthermore
column2: Majid Aqababaei
column3: the director general for border affairs of Iran’s Interior Ministry
column4: acknowledged
column5: as reported by Shana
column6: that an explosion near Iran’s border had caused the problem.

column1: Iran is Turkey’s second supplier of gas after Russia
column2: providing one-fifth of the country’s consumption. The current volume of natural gas that Iran is piping to its northwestern neighbor is 30 million cubic meters per day (mcm/d). Officials in Tehran had already emphasized that the Islamic Republic is ready to increase its gas exports to Turkey by 6 mcm/d.

column1: Iran has also for long been working on a plan to export its natural gas to Europe through Turkey. The plan – that was to be carried out though the Nabucco scheme – was eventually put on hold due to a series of technicalities. Nevertheless
column2: officials in Tehran announced last month that the possibility that gas exports to Europe would return to the agenda exist “if the requited agreements with Europeans countries over the plan are reached”. column4: and exports

column1: It is interesting to note that the Thai stock exchange actually experienced growth after the coup

column1: 7605;20041d0c723f2ce848274099bf4a4c935ca96cfc;0;;2016-10-28T18:02:48.492+03:00;Tony Blair suggests a second referendum to reverse Brexit;"Politics Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair says UK voters ‘have to build the capability to mobilize and to organize’ against Brexit.
Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair says Britain should keep its “options open” on whether or not to leave the European Union until after Brexit talks with the bloc are completed.
During an interview on Friday with BBC Radio 4's “Today” program
column2: Blair described the EU referendum as “a catastrophe” and said UK voters should be given the option of a second EU referendum.

column1: Britain should not withdraw from the EU until it becomes clearer how Brexit would impact UK’s economic
column2: social and cultural future

column1: The bizarre thing about this referendum is that we took a decision but we still don't know the precise terms
column2: ” he said. “There’s got to be some way
column3: either through parliament
column4: or through an election
column5: possibly through another referendum
column6: that people express their view.”

column1: The former premier
column2: who was in office from 1997 until 2007
column3: said it should be possible for the public to switch their verdict if it becomes clear the alternative negotiated by Prime Minister Theresa May is going to be worse.

column1: Blair’s argument contrasts sharply with that of May
column2: who has repeatedly said that “Brexit means Brexit” and that she’ll respect the referendum result. Blair had argued that Britain should stay in the EU before the referendum.

column1: Economic growth in the UK is expected to slow significantly next year

column1: If the UK loses its access to the EU’s single market

column1: The Fourth High Criminal Court of Bahrain has sentenced 15 political opponents to long jail terms and also revoked the citizenship of all of them. While several international rights groups have criticized the Al Khalifa regime’s harsh crackdown on the Bahraini opposition
column2: the Western powers turn a blind eye to the Arab state’s violations of human rights.

column4: as they’re condemned by the international human rights organizations and other organizations.”

column1: Manama has been cracking down on dissent since February 2011

7946;872a566948cad3f26ad9b624c9ce990358733ed9;0;Greg Freeman;2016-10-28T15:01:12.706+03:00;6 Myths That Men Believe About Southeast Asia;"I’ve been living in South East Asia for almost a decade now
column2: and over that time I’ve come to have a matured perspective on living here and a fair appreciation of the pros and cons of doing so. Like most people who come here
column3: I set off thinking I was going to live in paradise. That’s far from the reality
column4: let me tell you!

column1: Living in South East Asia has its pros and cons
column2: just like anywhere else. While I myself have decided to return west for a while
column3: I’ll always have a connection to Asia and I’m sure I’ll be back many times throughout my life.

column1: So what’s the REAL story with living in Asia? Is it all its cracked up to be? What does a man have to be aware of when coming here? Let’s look at six common stereotypical ideas about living in South East Asia
column2: and assess them in the light of reality.

column1: 1. Asian Women Are Kind
column2: Gentle
column3: And Compliant To Their Husbands So sweet! Not so fast….

column1: This is
column2: most definitely
column3: a myth
column4: and if you come out here expecting to find some little house pet who does your bidding
column5: you’ll be in for a rude awakening.

column1: It’s definitely true that Asian women
column2: in my experience
column3: are a lot more traditional. They give the man his place in the house
column4: rarely question your final decisions
column5: and do not resent housework and basic wifely duties.

column1: However
column2: the idea that they’ll just do whatever you tell them without question is nonsense. They’re human beings with a will of their own and you wouldn’t be the first guy to get a smack in the head from a five-foot-two broad who weighs 90 pounds if you disrespect her.

column1: The idea that Asian women are some sort of angelic alternative to Western women is also nonsense. While it’s not the norm
column2: I’ve met several Western men who have been taken to the cleaners by their Asian wives and girlfriends. When you move here
column3: you’re completely at her mercy and you will never have any legal rights as a citizen.

column1: Asian women generally are a lot more traditional
column2: but this stereotype that they’re some sort of perfect wife material has got to go. They’re individuals—and there are all kinds
column3: good and bad
column4: among them.

column1: Read this guide to dating Asian women for a more complete perspective on the issue. It’s a thorny subject
column2: and there’s a lot of misunderstanding surrounding it.

column1: 2. Asia Is Ridiculously Cheap
This is one I’d have to lean slightly towards agreeing with.
Most things in Asia are a lot cheaper. Eating out for my entire family often costs less than $15
column2: meaning I can afford to do it basically every day. My rent for a condo apartment costs less than $150 a month
column3: although that’s mostly because I live in the sticks and am not in a major city.

column1: A general rule of thumb is that outside of major cities like Bangkok
column2: Singapore
column3: and KL
column4: you can divide the cost of living by three and get a rough estimate.

column1: Note
column2: this does not apply to consumer goods such as cars and electrical appliances
column3: which are in and around the same price. It certainly does not apply to luxury goods
column4: which are often much more expensive because of the taxes placed on them by local governments.

column1: Asia is cheaper overall
column2: but anything other than the basics costs roughly the same. Life in South East Asia CAN be cheaper
column3: but it isn’t necessarily so—it depends on your lifestyle.

column1: 3. You Can Become A Citizen Of An Asian Country And Stay Forever Becoming a citizen in an Asian country is nigh on impossible. Even if you could
column2: you probably wouldn’t want to.

column1: You can get a variety of visas like permanent residency
column2: and each country aims to facilitate the spouses of their nationals and
column3: especially
column4: retirees with proven cash in the bank. However
column5: you’ll not become a CITIZEN with all of the various rights they enjoy.

column1: It’s also worth noting: while you might get permanent residence
column2: you’ll never be “one of them.” Even if you live here for 30 years
column3: you will always be a foreigner and will be viewed as such by locals. This has pros and cons to it
column4: but you’ll never quite feel at home and accepted as one of the group.

column1: You’ll get undue respect from some for being a Westerner
column2: but forget about talking politics or leveling criticisms at the way things are done—you’ll be met with hostility and resentment for the latter.

column1: 4. The Weather In Asia Is 24/7 Sunshine
The weather in South East Asia is generally pretty awesome
column2: and you can live an outdoors life you’ll truly enjoy if you’re that type.

column1: The sun shines almost every day
column2: and even when it’s overcast it’s warm
column3: meaning you can go out and about and do anything from walk on the beach to shop in the city.

column1: However
column2: when the storms come
column3: you’d better be prepared to get your ass inside. The rainfall and wind in many countries in South East Asia is truly terrifying. Just switch on any news station the next time a major storm hits the Philippines and you’ll see what it’s like.

column1: Thankfully
column2: after 1.5 years of living in the Philippines
column3: I’ve never been caught directly in a major storm
column4: although I’ve seen the tail end of plenty of them.

column1: The weather is good when it’s good
column2: and utterly awful when it’s bad. Check this clip out to see how bad it can get:

column1: 5. Asia Is 100 Years Behind The West In Terms Of Development
This is a stereotype that’s deeply mistaken
column2: and whether or not it’s true depends on which country you go to.

column1: True
column2: countries like Laos and Bangladesh are miles behind any Western nation
column3: but head to Singapore and you’ll be shocked by how far ahead of us they are in terms of tech and development.

column1: Asia is developing at breakneck pace
column2: and with that development comes super highways
column3: skytrains
column4: skyscrapers and everything else we usually associate with an advanced country. It won’t be long before many countries out here catch up and surpass the West
column5: although it is definitely true that most of them are slightly behind for now.

column1: There’s a phenomenon called “leapfrogging” which virtually guarantees Asian countries will catch up to and surpass the West quickly. Leapfrogging is when they can skip all of the evolution and development and simply emulate modern day technology developed elsewhere—a great example is India
column2: where they have skipped the transition from dial-up to mobie internet and gone straight from nothing to mobile.

column1: If you think this can’t be done and there are intellectual property laws to protect tech from being stolen wholesale
column2: I salute you
column3: but I have to laugh. There are no such laws
column4: and even if there were
column5: nobody would bother to enforce them.

column1: On the other hand
column2: you still have many scenes like this outside your window when you get out of the main cities:

column1: 6. Asians Are Extremely Family Oriented Again
column2: this is one I lean towards agreeing with. There are exceptions to every rule
column3: but the family unit is extremely strong in Asia
column4: especially countries like the Philippines.

column1: I don’t want to wax lyrical or speculate as to why this is. It’s enough to acknowledge it as a fact and accept that it’s the case. 90% of the Asian people I have ever met and gotten to know from Indonesia to the Philippines to Thailand are devoted to their families to the extent that we’d consider it cult-like in most Western countries.
I pass no judgment on this whatsoever. It can be a great thing or a bad thing
column2: depending on your own perspective. I personally like it and think it’s something we’ve lost in many European countries
column3: and America
column4: too.

column1: This is an idea about Asia I agree with—the dedication to family above individuality is definitely true
column2: and so by default if you get into a relationship with an Asian woman
column3: be prepared for this.

column1: The family unit is the sun around which everything orbits in most Asian countries.
Living In Asia Summary Sorry to disappoint you
column2: fellas
column3: but you won’t find paradise in South East Asia.

column1: What you will find is a place with many opportunities
column2: pitfalls
column3: pros and cons
column4: but which I do not regret living in for a single second and which has come to be a large part of my life’s story.

column1: I came out for a year and stayed for almost a decade. However
column2: I’ve decided that time is now over and it’s time to go home.

column1: I’d love to hear about your experiences living or traveling in Asia. Do you find my perceptions to be accurate
column2: or do you have a different view?

7956;fdd1652358b4e36b80e368612866cd58d021d78a;0;Quintus Curtius;2016-10-31T22:01:00.138+02:00;How To Repair Strained Or Broken Relationships;A subject not often discussed is the topic of how to repair strained or broken relationships. It is one that comes up in everyone’s life
column2: so it will be useful to make a few suggestions about it here. We will talk about relationships from friends
column3: family
column4: and lovers.

column1: Relationships among friends we will treat first. The first step in this process is to make an evaluation to determine whether the relationship is worth saving or rehabilitating. It is a simple fact of life that some relationships have an expiration date; when two people no longer have anything in common
column2: or their paths take them in divergent directions
column3: it may be difficult to find common ground. In this situation
column4: it is always better to let the relationship die a natural death slowly
column5: rather than rapidly. Abrupt terminations may leave the other party with negative feelings
column6: and this should be avoided if at all possible.

column1: There are some instances where repair is not possible. When someone has committed a fundamental violation of trust or respect
column2: this is a warning sign that the person was never a friend in the first place. Another point to keep in mind is that repair of a broken relationship requires—no
column3: demands—the participation of both parties. If the other person is unwilling to participate in the process
column4: then your efforts will be futile
column5: and will come to nothing.

column1: Once we have determined that the friendship is worth repairing or sustaining
column2: the next step is to decide how to make the first approach to the other party. In this we must try to evaluate the reasons for the problems in the first place. We should make an honest assessment about how things got to where they are. Did someone say or do something that caused hard feelings on the other side? Was there some intervening cause that made the two parties diverge in plans and activities? These types of questions must be honestly and repeatedly asked. We have a tendency to minimize our own hurtful actions and exaggerate those of others
column3: and this must be kept in mind.

column1: The key rule at this point is to try to put ourselves in the shoes of the other party. We must try to see things from our friend’s perspective. For many people this can be difficult
column2: as it involves getting past our own feelings of hurt or rejection and into the shoes of the other person. And yet it is essential. Very frequently the reasons for strained or broken friendships lies in the fact that there is some problem going on in the other person’s life. Only by being a perceptive student of human nature can we divine the cause. Sometimes the only thing that caused the strained relationship was some misunderstanding that was easily curable.

column1: Keep in mind that we must try—at least in our own minds—to discover the source of the other person’s problem. This is not always possible
column2: as human beings are not always rational. But we can at least make the effort. I remember in the film Hoffa that there was a great line from Jack Nicholson. He told one of his men
column3: “Real problems
column4: real grievances can be resolved. They can be negotiated. But imaginary grievances? That man is going to hate you for life.” I have no idea if Jimmy Hoffa every actually said this
column5: but it sounds like something he would have said. He meant that we should avoid hurting the pride of our friends. We should be acutely aware how it is sometimes the intangible slights that can most rankle with a man.

column1: When you have decided to make the first step
column2: it is always better to initiate contact directly. Do not wait for the other person to do it. Depending on the circumstances
column3: this should be done discreetly and without too much in the way of overpowering insistence. There is a certain type of finesse that a man should have at critical times
column4: and this is one of them. The approach should be direct
column5: but neither insistent nor demanding. A fish is best hooked with a lure gently laid.

column1: Of vital importance here is that the approach be sincere. One should genuinely want to contact the other party. Sincerity is the glue that binds friendships together and permits their longevity. There should be no hypocrisy or falsity in any of our dealings with friends. This kind of thing is immediately apparent and
column2: once detected
column3: its whiff surrounds the offending party like a permanent cloud. If the other party is receptive to the approach
column4: we can then gradually feel our way forward
column5: taking care to avoid the reasons why the friendship became strained in the first place. Things may never quite go back to what they were
column6: but at least we can find solid ground for a new frame of reference.

column1: Two examples will suffice here. The historian William Shirer worked closely with famed correspondent Edward R. Murrow when the two were in Germany in the 1930s. Yet after the war was over
column2: the two grew apart. Shirer’s account of the estrangement suggests that he was repelled by Murrow’s enthusiastic adoption of the anticommunist hysteria of the time. Shirer found himself gradually blackballed from most major news networks before being forced out completely. He broke with Murrow over these events. Many decades later
column3: he approached Murrow; all venom spent
column4: the two were able to find common ground again.

column1: Another example makes the same point. Theodore Roosevelt was a strong-willed
column2: insistent man
column3: to say the least. He was in a position to choose his successor as president
column4: and to this end he selected a man very different from him
column5: the affable and rotund William Howard Taft. Taft eventually began to find Roosevelt an overbearing and unwelcome presence in his life. The two men eventually broke completely
column6: a result of their personality differences and different conceptions of leadership. To his credit
column7: Roosevelt eventually approached his old friend privately to patch things up. They were never the same
column8: of course
column9: but at least some cordiality was restored.

column1: Relationships with family are of a fundamentally different sort. Because we are linked by bonds of blood (or perhaps marriage)
column2: it will be more difficult to disentangle ourselves from those with whom we have become estranged. On the other hand
column3: it may be easier to repair such grievances
column4: or at least find common ground
column5: since there may be more shared experiences with the other party that act in our favor. The key here is not to expect too much. Although shared history and common blood may work in our favor
column6: they can be counterbalanced to some extent by the fact that irrational family antagonisms can run deeper than those from strained friendships. Patience and persistence are most important here
column7: perhaps more so than friendships with those unrelated to us.

column1: Repairing strained relationships with lovers is perhaps the most difficult. When a man and woman have been united in the past through the coital act
column2: an entirely different set of emotions and motivations come into play. Relationships between lovers can fail or become strained for an infinite number of reasons
column3: and it would be impossible to discuss all of them here. It is enough for me to state my opinion that it is nearly impossible to bring an intimate sexual relationship back to what it was after it has been broken.

column1: Strained is one thing; broken is quite another. My own experience leads me to believe that once a sexual relationship is done
column2: it is done. One cannot really go back to what it was before. Amicable dealings are certainly possible
column3: and happen all the time; but I would not call this friendship. I would call it an uneasy equilibrium. Love’s inflammatory presence scorches all it leaves in its wake.

7964;06661d61518c55384ed4184ec0268b31e8b03b67;0;David G. Brown;2016-11-02T23:01:13.657+02:00;Feminists Attack Elderly Gay Man For Saying Older Women Shouldn’t Wear Yoga Pants;…not since the mini-skirt has there been something worn by so many women who should never have it on in the first place…
— Alan Sorrentino
column2: a sexagenarian gay man
column3: in his letter to a local Rhode Island newspaper

column1: A senior citizen and self-described “short
column2: little gay Italian” in Rhode Island has been the victim of a vicious intimidation campaign by feminists with too much time on their hands. After he wrote a newspaper letter saying that women over 20 should not wear yoga pants
column3: the backlash against Alan Sorrentino was vitriolic. 300 women marched on his home
column4: which was publicly shared
column5: using the excuse that it was just a “neighborhood protest.”

column1: In retaliation for exercising his First Amendment rights
column2: which you might have incorrectly thought encouraged violence given the heavy-handed feminist response
column3: Sorrentino received threatening calls and explicit death threats. Publications such as The Washington Post regarded the shameful intimidation of an old man as some kind of fun outing. Rabid social media users and the protesters themselves also lost sight of the context of Sorrentino’s letter and later comments
column4: which pointed out that men rocking up to supermarkets in Speedos would be considered inappropriate
column5: too.

column1: “Violent” gay man whose fashion prescriptions in a newspaper reaching only a few thousand people are capable of disemboweling feminists and ejecting them into space.
If anything
column2: the moronic march on Sorrentino’s home and throughout his neighborhood demonstrates the paucity of real issues women have to complain about. For all the talk of the “misogyny” and “patriarchy” that triggered the march (pun intended)

7984;bdb5eff72ed7ee14bdb020b6d192beac537d8964;0;Corey Savage;2016-11-07T19:00:00.000+02:00;6 Reasons Why You’re Not Happy;  6 Reasons Why You’re Not Happy 6 Reasons Why You’re Not Happy
Corey is an aspiring iconoclast. He believes that the key to life is for men to honour their primal nature.
Learn more about his views at theprimalmale.com You can also follow him on Twitter . November 7
column2: 2016 Mind

column1: Happiness: it’s what we all want as human beings no matter the differences in where we seek them. We are motivated to do things to be happy and we avoid things that may detract from it. Even those who claim that they don’t care about happiness or that they’re living for a higher purpose is doing what they do because it makes them happy. In that way
column2: happiness is beyond a state of feeling; it is a state of being.

column1: Now
column2: although you don’t want to be obsessive about happiness and make your life revolve around attaining it
column3: there are few things you can do to live a more fulfilling life and improve the quality of your being. And as it’s often the case with self-improvement
column4: I believe that addressing the bad habits will lead to a healthier life than trying to gain the positives.

column1: Here are some ways you may be sabotaging your own happiness. 1. You are chasing it “I’ll be happy once I finally…”
The more you chase happiness
column2: the less you have of it. And not only are people today chasing happiness
column3: they’re chasing all the wrong things in hopes that it will bring them everlasting joy. Money
column4: women
column5: and status may elevate your life
column6: but they can’t be the source of happiness alone. They will especially fail as being compensation for some void in your life that you’re trying to fill.

column1: Also
column2: know that your mood will naturally fluctuate over time. Constantly obsessing over how you feel and getting stressed over your emotional state will not help you. So
column3: rather than jumping from one thing to another in hopes that it will boost your mood or dull your pain
column4: focus on things that matter to you. It’s far better to work on self-improvement and enhancing the overall quality of your life than be wavered by feelings. 2. You don’t have the basics taken care of Good sleep is extremely underrated in our busy society. It affects your mood
column5: testosterone level
column6: mental capacity
column7: and more. Prioritize sleep as much as you do with healthy diet and working out.

column1: It’s often the basics that are overlooked. Ask yourself: Are you sleeping well (it’s harder to tell than you think)? Are you eating healthy? Are you keeping yourself fit? Are you getting enough sunlight? Do you ever take the time to connect with nature? Do you have a stable life? Do you have a purpose or a meaning? I doubt most people have all of these basic needs checked off. But I’m willing to bet that an improvement in even one area will significantly improve a person’s mood and well being. 3. You concern yourself with things you can’t control “No! Something bad is happening in the world and I can’t do jack shit about it! Time to complain about it on the internet.”
The more you sweat over issues which you can take no practical action over
column2: the more helpless you feel and the more unhappy you will be. Of course
column3: being able to tell the difference between what you can control and what you can’t is an art in itself that you need to master through experience. One thing I’m personally doing to lower stress is to reduce my news consumption and be less concerned with events around the world that are irrelevant to my personal life. I’ll read enough to get a general awareness of what’s happening around the world
column4: but I refuse to be emotionally invested in things I have no control over. 4. You lack intimacy and deep human connection If you don’t have any friends to be vulnerable with
column5: you didn’t have any to begin with.

column1: I would argue that this is one of the biggest
column2: if not the biggest factor in causing anxiety
column3: depression
column4: and general unhappiness in the modern world. Humans are social creatures and we need to bond with others. And beyond simply spending time with people to chat and drink
column5: deeper connection needs to be made with people. The quality matters much more than the quantity.

column1: In today’s society—especially in North America—it seems people have all become superficial and afraid of intimacy whether it be for friendship or romance. Without opening up your true self due to the fear of being rejected or ridiculed
column2: all the relationships you have with others will not be genuine and it will not be fulfilling. 5. You are not living in the present reality You may be conscious
column3: but are you aware?

column1: If you live in the past or the future
column2: you lose touch with the present reality. That disconnection will cause longing which can only lead to dissatisfaction and loss of joy.

column1: The lure of nostalgia and daydreaming of a better life or an improved world is actually quite insidious because of how intoxicating it is. When your mind drifts to imagining a pleasurable experience or a more exciting life
column2: you are tricked into thinking that the longing is happiness itself
column3: sort of like how mirages work. On the contrary
column4: studies have actually shown that you are actually happier (and more productive) when you focus on what you’re doing right now even if the task is boring. So
column5: stick to the reality and forget about your fantasies. Either make things happen or accept that you’re just wasting your time and energy on wishful thinking. 6. You engage in junk activities “I’m happy
column6: I’m happy
column7: I’m happy…”

column1: Just as there are junk foods
column2: there are junk activities that may feel pleasurable at the time but dissatisfying and even harmful in the long-run.

column1: Ask yourself: do you really need entertainment? I’ve squandered my youth by immersing myself in long hours of digital entertainment day after day. I barely even noticed that I was unhappy the whole time because I was so sedated. And what did I even get out of them? Those were several hours everyday that I could have spent reading
column2: working out
column3: learning new skills
column4: meeting new people
column5: and experiencing the world.

column1: The fact is
column2: giving up on entertainment has no negative impact on your level of happiness. Sure
column3: you might miss them when they’re suddenly gone
column4: but overall
column5: as long as you find more valuable things to do
column6: your life can only get better when you ditch them. Learn to enjoy things that give you value rather than seeking enjoyment in things without value. Conclusion

column1: Unlike what many people today say
column2: no one deserves happiness; that’s something you’ll have to earn. I’ll go as far as to say that “happiness”—as defined by modern standards—isn’t even necessary and hard to come by for certain individuals. Everyone has their own path towards living life to his unique potential and there is no universal rule that applies to all. So while I haven’t really listed anything specific for the reader to strive towards
column3: I hope I laid out some pitfalls that you can avoid in your journey. Nov 7
column4: 2016 Corey Savage";english;2016-11-07T22:03:39.272+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;6 Reasons Why You’re Not Happy;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 7987;b1396d7d40ce7f3a58de9058d996ba0a3d3f317f;0;Kyle Trouble;2016-11-08T18:01:22.038+02:00;6 Things To Know About Prague (Czech Republic);"A “gateway” between Western and Eastern Europe lies on the Charles River in the Czech Republic—Prague. It’s been a Western tourist hotspot for many years now. Many people consider it a city “overrun” by the Westerners. Ruined
column2: and no longer worth it.

column1: I’ve spent the last month of my travels here in Prague
column2: and have had a good opportunity to contrast to a place further east– Ukraine.

column1: With that being said
column2: here are 10 observations I’ve made about Prague.

column1: 1. Yes
column2: It’s Overrun
column3: BUT…

column1: That doesn’t mean you can’t find places that aren’t overrun. Yes
column2: if you choose to stay in Prague zone 1
column3: you’re going to have a drastically different experience. There will be hoards of people with selfie sticks
column4: and fat Western girls wobbling all over Old Town (blocking the already narrow streets).

column1: If you head out to Prague 2
column4: etc.
column5: you’ll have a much different experience. You’ll get to meet some locals
column6: try beer other than Staropramen
column7: and avoid the throngs of tourists.

column1: Of course
column2: it’s important to note that Prague is a beautiful city. It’s natural to want to see some of the sights. If you choose to go this route
column3: there’s simply no way around it.

column1: 2. The Reaction From Locals Changes Over Time
Simply put
column2: locals are used to Westerners. And most of them roll their eyes at them. However
column3: once they know that you’ve laid down some semi-permanent roots
column4: they’re far more friendly.

column1: Just the cashiers at the market below my apartment have done a complete 180 on me in the few weeks I’ve been here. It went from a general coldness that they show all English speakers to genuine warmth.
3. The Beauty (Of The City) Is Unreal
This is my third time in Prague
column2: and I’m still blown away by how beautiful of a city it is. From the castle to the riverwalks to all the colorful buildings
column3: it’s just a very pleasant place to be. There are a lot of beautiful cities in Europe
column4: but Prague is definitely near the top of all of them.

column1: You can’t really blame people for wanting to come and see it.
4. Cheap By Western Standards
column2: Expensive By EE Simply put
column3: if you’re looking for short-term rentals—you’re getting hosed. And there’s not many ways around it. Prague landlords know the power of Western currency and know that the short-term stag parties don’t mind blowing it.

column1: It’s far
column2: far cheaper to sign a lease for a 3
column4: or 12 month period.

column1: A meal in a nice restaurant will probably run you between $8-12 USD. This is incredibly cheap compared to places like Italy
column2: Spain
column3: or London. At the same time
column4: it’s definitely a bit more expensive than places such as Kiev
column5: Budapest
column6: or some cities in Poland.

column1: If you want actual numbers
column2: I’d say it’s about 30% more expensive than Kiev. Probably about 10-15% more expensive than Budapest (the last time I was there was April 2015
column3: so keep that in mind)
column4: and just marginally more expensive than Poland.

column1: Of course (as I keep harping on this)
column2: it’s going to get cheaper the further you go from the Old Town area.

column1: 5. The Girls
I know this is probably a large part of the reason you’re reading this. So let’s break it down. The girls are hot. They’re not as hot as Ukrainian and Russian girls
column2: but they’re a step above Polish women.

column1: At this point
column2: it’s easy to see that any and all local Czech girls living in Prague are basically immune to foreigners. You aren’t going to impress a girl by swooping in for a weekend and renting out a great pad with a view of the Old Town. In fact
column3: she’d probably rather do almost anything but hang out in that area.

column1: However
column2: being a foreigner will give you some major value if you’re living there. In Colombia
column3: girls will bang you just because you’re a foreigner. In Ukraine
column4: they’ll probably at least give you one date for being foreign. In Prague
column5: they’ll do neither— especially the high quality ones.

column1: However
column2: the same things apply if you’re living there (or coming back consistently).

column1: Plus
column2: it’s not exactly rocket science to be higher value than the drunken tourists stumbling around. Just keep your liquor in check
column3: and avoid putting a GoPro on your head–you’ll already be ahead of the game.

column1: 6. Conclusion—Is It Livable?
When you come from a place like Ukraine
column2: Prague feels much more like home. The English is better

column1: The question is whether or not it’s worth it to deal with what comes with those Western amenities—high amounts of tourism and a general feel of it being taken over. column1: You could do a lot worse.

column1: 7995;a50c947f770caf2c0274d7b67478ded9f69438a4;0;Michael Sebastian;2016-11-10T23:00:59.603+02:00;What The 2016 Election Has Exposed;"There are some things that we have learned about the United States from this election. We’ll need to keep these in mind as we make efforts to return sanity to society.

The federal government has been corrupted Probably the most shocking lesson of this election is that the entire federal government has been coopted to serve a single party—the Democrats. The best example of this was the behavior of FBI Director James Comey. The FBI is part of the Executive branch of government so Comey reports to Loretta Lynch
column2: who in turn reports to Obama. Despite this fact
column3: one expects that the FBI be allowed a high degree of discretion to honestly investigate individuals regardless of which political party they belong to. After all
column4: the US was founded upon the idea that we are all equal before the law.

column1: Comey’s actions reveal that the FBI has thrown equality before the law out the window. At first the FBI investigated Clinton’s use of an unsecure
column2: personal email server to conduct national business while she was Secretary of State. But even though Clinton apparently violated several laws that have gotten other people severe jail sentences
column3: Comey exonerated her back in July with a hand slap.

column1: In a move that surprised everyone
column2: Comey re-opened on October 28th the criminal investigation of Clinton after 650
column3: 000 emails State Department emails were found on pervert Anthony Weiner’s computer. Trump supporters rejoiced and Hillary supporters expressed outrage. But the White House calmly called Comey “a man of integrity.” Did they know something we didn’t?

column1: It turns out the fix was in from the beginning because just 48 hours before election day
column2: Comey exonerated Clinton again . The FBI director likely intended to clear Clinton of wrongdoing before the election to defuse Donald Trump’s criticism of her.

column1: The big lesson is that the law is applied selectively. Wealthy
column2: politically-connected people don’t need to play by the same rules as everyone else. Unless this situation is corrected
column3: it means the rule of law is dead—and that is a very grave lesson indeed.

column1: The elites are in control but… Elites want you to believe they are super smart and super powerful like the Great Oz.
I’ve written many times about the control that globalist elites exert on the country through their control of the media
column2: educational institutions
column3: and politicians through the form of bribes (donations
column4: cushy job offers
column5: speaking fees). By controlling the flow of information and setting the narrative
column6: the globalists are able to control the masses like cattle. The good news is that their control is not complete. They are not omnipotent.

column1: The weakness of the elites has been demonstrated in three ways. The first was with the Brexit vote. When Prime Minister David Cameron agreed to hold a referendum on the UK’s membership in the EU
column2: he never dreamed that Britons would actually vote to leave. All the polls at the time showed that any movement to leave would go down in flames. Still
column3: through the work of men like Nigel Farage and Boris Johnson
column4: the British populace voted to leave the EU. The Brits on the leave side had to endure being called racist and look past polling that said they had no chance to win.

column1: The second way was the campaign of Trump himself. The GOP had planned a coronation for Jeb Bush. The rest of the GOP field was “me too” candidates who were virtually indistinguishable from Jeb. Trump came in with an uncompromising message and crushed Jeb and the rest of the little Jebs. The elite plan to have Hillary versus a weak conservative was completely thrown into disarray by Trump’s campaign. Even if Trump has lost the general
column2: it is still a victory because now
column3: instead of seeing the Great Oz
column4: we see the globalists behind the curtain.

column1: The third manifestation of the weakness of the elites is the rise of the Alt Right. A tiny group of young people on the internet was able to quickly wake up large segments of the population. Only a year ago
column2: terms like nationalism and globalism were rarely heard in the US. Now
column3: we have grandmothers in Texas tweeting about how we need to lay the axe to the globalists.

column1: The overall lesson is that we should not fear the globalist elite. They exist and they are able to fool a majority of the population
column2: but not all of us. With sound strategy
column3: they can be defeated.

column1: The Elite have completely divorced themselves from non-elites
In the past
column2: Europe had an aristocracy. This aristocracy had a close relationship with the rest of the people in the country. The aristocracy was expected to defend the nation in case of war. They also had the same religion as the rest of the country. We already knew that the modern “aristocracy” of the globalist elites has no responsibilities toward the rest of us
column3: but
column4: thanks to WikiLeaks
column5: we have now learned that they don’t even share the same religion.

column1: WikiLeaks revealed that Hillary Clinton and her campaign manager are close friends with Marina Abramovic
column2: a Serbian artist who performs occult rituals she calls “ spirit cooking .” Spirit cooking appears to be set of magical rituals that use bodily fluids such as menstrual blood
column3: urine
column4: and semen to achieve certain goals
column5: usually sex-related. It also involves at least minor sacrifices: one “recipe” calls for cutting one’s figure and “eat[ing] the pain.”

column1: While spirit cooking is certainly grotesque
column2: it is not my intention to focus on it except to point out that it has become a sort of initiation ritual into the US globalist elite. Hillary Clinton
column3: John Podesta
column4: Jay-Z and Beyonce
column5: Lady Gaga
column6: and Gwen Stefani have all attended these rituals and I would not be surprised to learn that many other politicians
column7: CEOs
column8: and bankers also participate. Getting invited to one of these spirit cooking sessions means that you have gained entry into the wealthy elite in the US. There are probably similar groups or rituals for the modern day European elites.

column1: There are several things at work here. Most of the spirit cooking participants probably don’t believe in the efficacy of the spirit cooking ritual. It is more like a college fraternity initiation. It only means something in terms of one’s social standing. Also
column2: the satanic imagery of spirit cooking and its sexual overtones are big middle fingers to Christianity which our elite regard as the religion of the unwashed masses.

column1: In both of these ways
column2: our modern “elite” have separated themselves from the rest of us. They don’t share the same destiny as us. If the country starts going to hell
column3: the wealthy elite can just pick up and move to another country or they can live in small
column4: heavily guarded compounds
column5: untouched by the damage their policies have caused. And they even lack a common morality with us. In their own eyes
column6: their wealth has somehow put them beyond the traditional moral code that guides the rest of us.

column1: The fact that the elites have no regard for the rest of the country does not bode well for them. The aristocracy of old knew that their fortune was bound up with that of their countrymen. The modern elite lack this wisdom. Once enough of the hoi polloi realize it
column2: it is only a matter of time before these pseudo-elites are deposed from their pedestal.

column1: Conclusion With Trump’s election
column2: the problem of federal government being used for political purposes will be mitigated. However
column3: the problems with our indulgent pseudo-elite will continue to be a force that prevents the patriarchy from returning. In any case
column4: we can be grateful that the election of 2016 has exposed some of the cancers that are eating away at our society.

column1: It will be easier to find a fellow traveler
Men who hold our beliefs have long ago learned that we can’t go around sharing them in public to those who are not vetted. If you’re like me

column1: The cultural decline will halt
We now have a President who will not encourage anti-male propaganda
column2: rape culture
column3: and female victimhood. While I do have minor concerns on the influence of his feminist-minded daughter
column4: Ivanka
column5: Trump will not continue the attack on men that has been institutionalized since the sexual revolution and accelerated during the eight years of Obama. Because our current cultural dystopia is the result of intense long-term manipulation

column1: We’ve experienced so many changes in the past decade that we haven’t had a chance to understand what’s going on and adapt. Instead
column2: we’ve been reacting from one blow to the next
column3: whether it’s the loss of our jobs through witch hunts or the rape culture horror that has turned a banal consensual hookup into possible incarceration. Trump’s victory gives us room to begin pushing back against the fictions that have put men in harm’s way.

column1: Conclusion Paradoxically
column2: the benefits of a Trump presidency will not involve specific actions from Trump. His presence automatically legitimizes masculine behaviors that were previously labeled sexist and misogynist. While we may still get heat for them
column3: it will be less severe and we’ll be less likely to sustain serious damage. Liberals will have no choice but to silently stew on our words and we can more effortlessly connect with men not only for male bonding but also to push back against a demoralized and fractured left. Victories will be far easier to achieve under Trump than Obama.

column1: This is our moment. The door is opening for a renaissance of masculinity where men can take pride in being men
column2: and the best part of it is that we don’t need to wait for Trump to do anything. His victory is more than enough for us to apply our own individual strength in seizing the bull’s horns where we can come out of the politically incorrect closet and assert our beliefs and behaviors. It would be icing on the cake if Trump rolled back anti-masculine laws and policies
column3: but it’s not required

column5: and the only surprise for me is how quickly the name is being fulfilled.

column1: 8002;b465ae774250298095ce62b694868c4e7e4475a0;0;Larsen Halleck;2016-11-13T21:01:44.275+02:00;Why You Should Be Doing The Twist Stretch;"As I have repeatedly shown in my articles
column2: I am a fan of all aspects of fitness—not just strength and developing muscular mass
column3: but also cardiovascular endurance and flexibility as well. You likely knew this already.

column1: You are also likely aware that I have done several articles on stretching
column2: most recently the “relax into stretch” technique that I state can be used predominantly for lower body stretching such as the splits
column3: which are and will likely always be considered the benchmark of hip and leg flexibility.

column1: But what about upper body flexibility? Most people don’t focus on that
column2: and that is just as important to train as lower body flexibility (namely for purposes of increased athletic performance
column3: reduction of joint aches and pains
column4: and
column5: in some cases
column6: increased strength). I have taught the readers some basic upper body stretches in the past
column7: such as the chest stretch and the door frame stretch. But in my opinion
column8: if you’re going to do any one stretch for upper body flexibility
column9: that would have to be the seated twist stretch.

column1: How It Works This stretch involves crossing your legs in a manner that will be discussed below
column2: and twisting the torso while simultaneously locking your arm onto your bent knees. This stretch will hit most of your most prominent upper body muscles—the latissimus dorsi
column3: the triceps
column4: the deltoids
column5: the obliques
column6: the neck
column7: and the pectorals.

column1: In addition to those visible muscles
column2: the twist stretch will work the deep spinal muscles
column3: and even the muscles of the buttocks (the gluteus maximus
column4: medius and minimus) as well.

column1: Many athletes perform the twist stretch
column2: particularly combat athletes such as wrestlers
column3: judokas
column4: and mixed martial artists that need great torso flexibility to escape from holds and pinfalls.

column1: Sounds like something you ought to learn
column2: doesn’t it? But how?

column1: As I have happily admitted in the past
column2: and will likely do so again
column3: Paul Wade’s outstanding Convict Conditioning series has taught me this and many other exercises
column4: and I cannot advocate Wade’s writing enough. More specifically
column5: the Twist Stretch comes from Convict Conditioning 2 . The first book deals with the core calisthenic series—push-ups
column6: squats
column7: and the like. I have already gone over these in detail. In contrast
column8: the second book deals with static holds that develop strength and flexibility such as the L-Sit and today’s topic.

column1: While the third book deals with explosive movements such as the back and front handsprings
column2: that will be a topic for another time. Instead
column3: let’s go into the steps of the Twist Stretch.

column1: All of the pictures here are taken directly from the book.
The Exercises The first twist stretch is the “Easy twist stretch.” Sit down on the floor with your feet extended. Take one foot
column2: and put it “inside” the other leg
column3: resting that foot next to the opposite knee
column4: as shown.

column1: Now
column2: twist your body so the opposite shoulder turns towards the raised kneed (ie: if the left knee is raised
column3: turn the right shoulder
column4: and vice versa). Keep the foot flat on the ground and the knee stationary-just twist the torso. Allow your neck to turn as it naturally wants to turn.

column1: Then
column2: “lock” your torso by placing your elbow against the opposite side of the knee
column3: while holding your body up with the other hand.

column1: You should immediately begin to feel a stretch all around your torso.
Hold the stretch for 10 seconds
column2: for each side. When this is comfortable for you
column3: move on.

column1: Step 2 is the simple twist stretch
column2: which requires a little bit more flexibility. Place one foot over the other leg as shown above. Then
column3: take the foot that is not flat on the ground
column4: bend the leg back and touch the heel of that foot to the opposing buttock (ie: the right heel touches the left buttock).

column1: This foot position will be used for all twist stretches from henceforth.
Now
column2: as before
column3: rotate your torso towards the opposite knee (right shoulder to left knee
column4: and vice versa)
column5: locking yourself by placing your elbow on the opposite side of the knee
column6: and again supporting your body with the other hand. Hold for 10 seconds
column7: and move on.

column1: Stretch 3 is where things become more difficult. Assume the position from Stretch #2. But this time
column2: you will have to rotate the torso with much more force
column3: as the goal of this stretch is to extend your arm and touch the instep of the foot that is flat on the floor. Your arm won’t be able to stretch on its own (and I don’t advise you try)
column4: you will have to accomplish this with proper torso rotation.

column1: Stretch 4 has the difficulty increase further: Get a hand towel or some other object that is about a foot long. Assume the stretching position
column2: and rotate the torso while holding said towel. Remove the supporting hand from the floor
column3: and flick the towel through the “hole” made by your raised leg (obviously your hand is not extending down to your instep here). Wrapping the “support” hand around your back
column4: grab the other end of the towel. This begins the stretch.

column1: Each time you stretch
column2: you will assume this position holding the towel in two hands. You will work your hands up and down the towel
column3: slowly bringing your hands together by gripping greater portions of the towel. Eventually
column4: you will be able to clasp fingers
column5: and that is the final level of the twist stretch.

column1: This process will be slow and arduous—“Coach Wade” himself admits that it took him the better part of a year to accomplish this by moving his fingers together inch by inch. I myself am not quite at the final level yet-a rough measurement shows that I have about 4 more inches of towel to go before my fingers touch
column2: but I have certainly noticed increased mobility and flexibility already.

column1: The towel stretch can be made easier by remembering to “worm” both hands up the towel
column2: not just one. Actively use both to secure deeper stretches
column3: and you will notice progress.

column1: Doing even the easiest variations of this stretch will make you notice an immediate healing of the spine: your back will deliciously crack and you’ll feel warm and limber afterwards. And with practicing the more advanced variants
column2: you will make yourself more limber for whatever physical activity you engage in
column3: ranging from dancing to getting out of submission holds.

column1: Or you could be one of millions of Americans with bad backs and hips. The choice is yours.

8010;4da2ff7aa4b1cb51212dd8c3bbbacf026a463283;0;4 Goals For The Neomasculinity Movement During Trump’s First Term;2016-11-16T18:07:48.392+02:00;Comment on Are You On Pace To Reach Your Goals? by 4 Goals For The Neomasculinity Movement During Trump’s First Term;Home This Month Popular Are You On Pace To Reach Your Goals? Are You On Pace To Reach Your Goals? February 2
column2: 2013 20 Comments Lifestyle

column1: Today is February 2
column2: 2013 and you’re one month closer to death. What have you done this year to improve yourself? Some may say New Years resolutions are cop-outs for actually setting reasonable goals
column3: instead of starting today we say “In a week I’ll hit the gym and finally get ripped!” I like the idea of coming up with goals and plans to achieve them for January 1st of the next year. The start of each year is a mental rebirth
column4: January 1 is a new snow begging for you to make fresh tracks in it
column5: a blank canvas yearning to be painted on.

column1: However
column2: many do use New Years resolutions to feel better about themselves. They gorge themselves on baked goods
column3: drink heartily and fail to exercise throughout the month of December telling themselves that “next year will be different” and “just one last time before I change.” This is not the case for us here at Return of Kings. We are different — writers
column4: readers
column5: and commenters all strive to build themselves into the man they want to be.

column1: Personally
column2: I had some slip-ups through the month of January
column3: but what sets the determined apart from the shambling masses is that we pick ourselves up and keep pushing forward one step at a time . I started the year off strong my days and nights booked full with dates
column4: time with girlfriends
column5: reconnecting with old friends. I eschewed online dating and become more social during the day time. I broke PRs on all of my lifts
column6: dropped a few pounds
column7: and sought coaching for the Olympic lifts.

column1: Most importantly I held myself accountable for all of my actions. If I ate too much
column2: drank too much or didn’t take opportunities I should have
column3: I picked myself up and adapted. Push forward and give everything you have. How bad do you want it? What happens when you reach your goal? Do you aim higher
column4: or do you stop there and remain content with being slightly above average ? If you choose the latter and have finite
column5: concrete goals you are already anticipating the day you can quit building yourself. You’re doomed for failure.Don’t ever miss an opportunity to get better
column6: take risks
column7: analyze your successes/failures
column8: and don’t stop until you’ve surpassed your goals. Then strive to be better
column9: faster and stronger.

column1: What are your goals for 2013? Are they SMART ? Do you have a purpose ? Do you want to have sex with more beautiful women
column2: learn a language
column3: lift more weight and make more money? Do you have an accountability buddy or do you journal and meticulously track your progress?

column1: How is your progress going? Feb 2

column7: Robert Duvall
column8: Brock Peters

column2: stupid

column5: stand-up
column6: straight-arrow black man
column7: Tom Robinson (Brock Peters)
column8: who is falsely accused of rape by a conniving
column9: white-trash slut named Mayella Ewell (Collin Wilcox)
column10: whose alcoholic father
column11: Bob Ewell (James Anderson)
column12: is a racist pig of unfathomably low character.

column2: Atticus Finch (Gregory Peck)

column4: wrongly accused black man

column6: which ultimately results in the backwater town’s killer cops shooting poor Tom down in cold blood (a familiar theme
column7: which can be abundantly found in today’s world of dindu-nothin’ black folk
column8: who are perennially and viciously gunned down by racist white cops
column9: on an ever-increasing and frightening basis…yawn

column1: I’m not even going to get into the rest of this mind-numbing film’s plot and story line

column3: which you might find just a little bit interesting… The SJW-controlled civil rights movement exploded with a vengeance not long after this film was released. And here’s the red-pill truth of the matter: according to the 1994 annual report on murder by the Federal Bureau of Investigation
column4: most interracial murders in the USA involved black assailants and white victims
column5: with blacks murdering whites at 18 times the rate that whites murder blacks.

column3: an upsurge which
column4: not so coincidentally enough
column5: corresponds exactly with the beginning of the modern SJW-crafted civil rights movement. Blacks thus committed 7.5 times more violent interracial crimes than whites
column6: even though the black population was only one-seventh the size of the white population at the time. This is according to the survey
column7: Highlights from 20 Years of Surveying Crime Victims

column1: These days
column2: Washington’s SJW data-gatherers no longer keep track of such “ bigoted ” statistics…probably because they care about our safety so very

column5: overwhelmingly involving black offenders and white victims
column6: and more than 45
column7: 000 people were killed in interracial murders—the vast majority of them being black-on-white killings. By comparison
column9: 000 Americans died in the Vietnam War
column10: and 34
column11: 000 were killed in the Korean War.

column1: I wonder how many additional people have been killed in America

column5: as previously mentioned

column1: Be that as it may
column2: the notions set forth in To Kill A Mockingbird are repulsively twisted
column3: morally insidious and patently false. And if that offends anybody out there who might be reading this review
column4: that makes my entire freaking day. Because in the end
column5: all that should matter to any critically thinking person is the truth. And what Hollywood dishes out on a regular basis
column6: is anything but… 2. Gandhi (1982 – Sir Ben Kingsley
column7: Martin Sheen
column8: Candice Bergen
column9: Sir John Gielgud)

column2: as the crafters of history have quite ingeniously led us to believe
column3: Mohandas K. Gandhi (played by Sir Ben Kingsley
column4: in this multiple-Oscar-winning film) utilized the greatest weapon of all in his epic fight against British tyranny on behalf of the Indian people—the incredibly effective method of non-violent resistance.

column1: And in the movie
column2: Gandhi

column4: as it faces down a group of security forces armed with sticks
column5: outside of a salt factory

column5: in this cleverly constructed movie

column1: And what Sheen’s character witnessed
column2: and put into words
column3: and then passed along to his editor over the phone

column1: Despite the fact that every single major worldwide event that finds its way into the mainstream media’s propaganda conduits

column3: IMHO)
column4: or something that meshes well with the elite’s overall master plan

column7: Gandhi
column8: depicts real-life events that occurred as the direct result of one brave man in a loincloth
column9: who stood up to the ferocious might of the British Empire and brought the entire house down
column10: single-handedly?

column1: Please. You’d have a better chance of talking me into using Tinder.
There is another infamous sequence in the film
column2: wherein a group of Hindi demonstrators is peacefully assembling in protest
column3: within an enclosed
column4: park-like area of the Indian city of Amritsar. The demonstrators are consequently assaulted by British soldiers
column5: who open fire
column6: brutally and randomly
column7: on the assembled sitting ducks
column8: and proceed to gun down hundreds of protesters (this incident allegedly occurred on April 13
column10: and some estimates put the actual number of demonstrators killed at well over 1000).

column1: And in this single
column2: crucial
column3: very revealing sequence of the film
column4: the sobering truth is once again put on display for all to see—assembling peacefully
column5: going against the grain of the established order
column6: by utilizing peaceful protest and non-compliance within a group setting

column4: and gunning down the peaceful demonstrators. But that was all done strictly for show. And this is most obviously a case of cinematic cover here
column5: as anyone who can think for themselves can easily infer (who do you think produced Gandhi …uh

column7: Columbia Pictures—do you really think the elite are going to pass along the bona fide solution to wiping them out…uh

column1: The British Empire has a long and bloody history of usurping lands. And the notion that the string-pullers at the very top of the greasy flagpole would be aghast at the actions of the British commander who ordered the slaughter at Amritsar

column1: What the slaughter at Amritsar actually accomplished (in addition to the mass-murder of a huge swath of ardent protesters) was the following:
With the complicit assistance of the elitist-owned press
column2: the British commander’s actions that day reinforced the suicidal notion that peaceful protest and non-violent resistance were the keys to bringing about significant social change. And throughout history
column3: other choreographed events like the slaughter at Amritsar and the subsequent explosion of moral outrage
column4: fueled by the reports in the elite-owned media
column5: have continued to give rise to the suicidal notion that non-violent resistance actually works.

column1: Which of course it does

column3: high-profile
column4: choreographed incidents
column5: where the outcome has already been decided beforehand
column6: whenever the Puppet Masters want it to appear that way to the sleeping sheep…the rest of the time
column7: it only results in mass-incarceration
column8: physical assault
column9: political harassment or murder. On a more subtle note
column10: you might have noticed that two of the leading actors in this Oscar-winning film were eventually knighted by the British Empire—namely
column11: Sir Ben Kingsley (knighted in 2001) and Sir John Gielgud (knighted in 1953)…to which I can only say
column12: “I rest my case
column13: Your Honor.” 3) The Gift (2015 – Jason Bateman
column14: Rebecca Hall
column15: Joel Edgerton
column16: Allison Tolman)

column1: I don’t typically watch modern Hollywood films these days. Mostly because I know what Hollywood is up to
