column1: 8020;2009f762eaf834a60f77f38653a992415eca0c9a;0;André du Pôle;2016-11-19T04:00:00.000+02:00;Men Are Binded By Their Shared Realization Of Truth;"  Men Are Binded By Their Shared Realization Of Truth Men Are Binded By Their Shared Realization Of Truth
André is a young European who left his decaying country in 2012 for greener pastures. He enjoys exploring subterranean places
column2: reading about a host of interconnected topics
column3: and yearns for Tradition. November 18
column4: 2016 Politics

column1: The 9 th of November 2016 was a great day. We will remember it as well as our parents remember the first moon landing in July 1969 or the fall of the Berlin wall. Liberal mainstream media—almost a pleonasm—are either stunned or agitating. Some of these crybullies clamour to themselves how “fearful” they are
column2: lament on the “destruction of the West”—a curious expression as it seldom appears under leftist pens—or have difficulties to acknowledge that the man they have despised and defamed every day for months will be the 45 th President of the United States.

column1: Outside the US
column2: The Donald’s victory is creating waves
column3: too. So many liberals allegedly connected to the Canadian Immigration website to crash it. In France
column4: the bourgeois bohemians who work in the media
column5: academia and everything that constitutes the big left establishment do the same posturing than their American counterparts
column6: whereas the petits blancs (impoverished
column7: disenfranchised whites) and local “righters” rejoice.

column1: In Brazil
column2: where your humble servant lives
column3: the official media is making some tedious comments that deliver a flabby criticism. Local leftist talking heads condemn the “ white protestants ” and reality shows in a very cliché posturing that mixes anti-white prejudice with a critique of capitalism
column4: whereas some new traditionalists
column5: among whom some have been avid readers and makers of Alt-Right content
column6: are grateful .

column1: This is our victory. Feels good
column2: man

column1: A pro-Pepe Facebook group has had a substantive discussion about where a red-pilled foreigner considering moving to the US after the Donald won should go. To make a long story short
column2: some have advised potential newcomers to go live in the Midwest
column3: in Texas as long as one stays away from Houston or Dallas
column4: in Wyoming for the gun rights
column5: in Pennsylvania excluding Philadelphia and the urban areas
column6: close to the Appalachian mountains if one enjoys outdoors
column7: while staying away from Illinois. Most of those who participated were whites
column8: but I have spotted some Latino and Arab names. Some made jokes on these names but no fuss.

column1: And here the following question arises. What defines us? Liberals have been shrieking about “xenophobia” or “racism” all the time. Yet
column2: strictly national boundaries are much less relevant than before
column3: even for us
column4: even when we all rejoiced about Trump’s promise to make a wall. All over the world we are rejoicing around the GOP candidate’s victory.

column1: American “Trumpists” undoubtedly feel closer to non-Americans who have been dissenting from the NWO on the Internet and wanted the Donald to pass than to American libtards. A lot of us are OK with having non-whites around: we don’t pander to arrogant
column2: aggressive anti-whites
column3: but that does not mean we would have to be “racists” as the liberal caricature wants us to be. To cut in more personally
column4: I know of no genuine red-pilled or Alt-Righter who would have rejected me as a frog
column5: although I remember some stars and stripes cucks blaming me for daring to speak about American politics without owning a US passport. The frog is green after all

column1: So
column2: once again
column3: what defines us? Why are we a “we”? Race plays a role for sure. We struggle to keep the white people from getting dissolved into the acid bath of wide-scale miscegenation and dispossession. We want a right to solidarity based at least partly on race
column4: i.e. on lineage and identity
column5: just like all the pseudo-minority groups out there. We fight the double standard that allows them to be communitarian
column6: tribalistic
column7: nepotistic
column8: without being ever responsible of what they do
column9: whereas we are supposed to keep our heads down and be taught everything by liberal social engineers in a world where we would have no freedom
column10: no future
column11: no dignity.

column1: But even then
column2: there have been Blacks
column3: Latinos
column4: and many women who participated into bringing The Donald to the White House. I have a race-mixed friend who supported Trump all along. This is not to say “I’m not a racist!
column5: ” afraid cuckservative-style
column6: but to show there are some and we know it firsthand.

column1: It is no mystery why most of us are white: we are united around a civilization that was primarily built by people of European descent. But there is more
column2: too.

column1: And this “more” that
column2: I think
column3: defines and binds us; this “more” is shared awareness . On the periphery of the System centers
column4: we managed to grow and gather

column1: We are all aware
column2: broadly speaking
column3: of the same phenomena and trends. We have witnessed the break-up of families and harmonious relationships between men and women. We have been faced with the untold prohibition to make the least critic of feminism
column4: “minority groups” aggressive identitarianism
column5: and with the pervasive omnipresence of these leftist norms commonly referred to as political correctness. We have seen neoliberalism allowing a handful of careless
column6: irresponsible assholes sending the jobs overseas
column7: importing third-world immigration
column8: then force us into a life of chronic unemployment or endless struggles against other low-wage individuals for a small place under the sun.

column1: We saw how conservatism was a sham that never faced the genuine problems. We witnessed societies crumble
column2: conflictual “minoritarian” group identities being crafted by the likes of Soros
column3: and the meritorious worker or professional—whatever his race—getting exploited to the benefit of the lower and upper parasites. We saw the liberal establishment using various social categories like pawns to create horizontal struggles and depopulation .

column1: Of course
column2: some disagreements can be found on this or that particular issue
column3: but we all see the same devastated landscape in lieu of the brilliant civilization the West once was.

column1: And here is the major fault line. The leftists deny or value —they often go from the former to the latter—the replacement of native European population
column2: the aggressive and tribalistic stance of “minority groups” towards the silent majority
column3: the forced inclusion of individuals into sick identity politics games
column4: the perpetual hostility and institutionalized prejudice against whites and males… Either the leftists utterly deny what we are aware of
column5: for example when they say that whites are not under replacement
column6: or they demonize it as a remnant of some “privilege” or “prejudice.”

column1: All their talk about “oppressed minorities” dissimulates the very real disenfranchisement of the white majority
column2: of non-white meritorious and integrated Westerners
column3: and serves to deny us from our rights to public empathy
column4: to dignity
column5: or to even basically survive in a world of our own. They work on language and representations because their job consists in manipulating these
column6: thus brainwashing us into seeing the world through their lenses and denying the legitimacy of any other vision.

column1: The importance of shared awareness explains why we united on the Internet. A lot of us were closet nationalists years ago
column2: and still are. We could not
column3: and often still cannot
column4: be nationalists in public
column5: or we would have been excluded from normal social life by the local leftists and cowards. Leftist hegemony was and is still real in the mainstream. You know hegemony when you see it and spend countless hours thinking about how you can thrive even when living under it.

column1: In the mid-2000
column2: I found out about the information website Fdesouche (“Native French”) quote. By the standards of today
column3: this news aggregator seems hardly interesting: it mostly collates pieces written by others. But then
column4: it was fantastic. Here I could recognize what I already felt about the world—that something was wrong with all these non-whites thugs holding the streets and getting lavish promotion when they bragged about it. It was all concentrated before my eyes
column5: and others were talking about what they went through daily as well. At least
column6: others felt and saw the same as I did! I was not crazy
column7: not bound to a life of unauthenticity or forlorn solitude among the almighty left. We were assembling. And we were on the Internet. “Fdesouche.com—The website they want to keep you from visiting”

column1: As most of us found ourselves under attack from non-native Frenchmen
column2: and knowing intuitively that identity goes deeper than the fleeting winds today called culture
column3: we often despised immigration in general. But eventually things changed
column4: thanks to Alain Soral
column5: mostly
column6: who emphasized how racial struggle was leading to sterile battles among disenfranchised people while letting the truly powerful off the hook. Mathias Cardet
column7: a black journalist who worked with Soral
column8: showed how gangsta-rap culture was injected and nurtured among non-whites by powerful interests.

column1: After all
column2: one can be black or Arab and wanting to live in peace as a free individual
column3: not as an identity politics pawn who spends his life attacking another social category.

column1: Being pro-white
column2: pro-masculinity and pro-tradition does not require being white: I often felt closer from Muslims with good intentions
column3: i.e. Muslims who were genuine believers and not rancorous people using Islam as a mask for anti-white tribalism
column4: than from white liberals. The Muslims would not share my blood
column5: but they would share some of my awareness and yearning for Tradition
column6: two things that white liberals eagerly reject. “Faith front
column7: warriors’ alliance against common foes”

column1: The Internet is immaterial. It is
column2: basically
column3: a network where information flows. Awareness
column4: and the will to spread it
column5: are immaterial as well. This is why we could meet and act on the Internet. After all
column6: the Alt Right and manosphere have been sharing ideas
column7: media contents
column8: memes
column9: advises—and only later proceeded to meetups
column10: panicking the totalitarian liberals in the process.

column1: Trump’s victory is a major one. Regardless of what The Donald will actually do
column2: it is an event of considerable historical magnitude. But it is only the beginning—make no mistake about that. The libtards’ establishment still holds loads of money
column3: of institutions
column4: of cultural territory. It has started to crumble and leak
column5: yet it is still there.

column1: Major battles are waiting ahead. We have to further our awareness
column2: make thorough research on every aspect of leftism
column3: and develop more proper cultural references.

column1: Always remember the libtards never cared one second about us. They would have let us die off
column2: alone
column3: poor
column4: childless
column5: traumatized and demonized
column6: had we not chosen to follow the path of the red pill.

column1: America is a first-tier power
column2: but it is still a battlefield among others. Wherever we are
column3: it is time to thicken our mutual relationships and cooperate more closely. It is a battle
column4: not between nationals and foreigners
column5: but between workers and parasites
column6: between those who feel the void and wrongness in the rotten core of postmodernity and those who dwell in the last liberal trend
column7: between the realists who want freedom and responsibility in a healthy world of values and cultures against those who ravel in blue pill
column8: media bullshit
column9: complacency
column10: parasitism and cucking for the empire of nothing.

column1: We are the future. It doesn’t matter where we are. We are those with true awareness
column2: those with genuine and healthy values
column3: those who struggled to hone their abilities
column4: and most importantly those who actually deserve to inherit the Western world. So
column5: save it and conquer it
column6: country after country
column7: institution after institution
column8: outlet after outlet—or there will be nothing left.";english;2016-11-19T13:39:04.804+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;Men Are Binded By Their Shared Realization Of Truth;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 8021;f18a087dd65ccde60e653596d2e838e56b263c35;0;GrahamSeibert;2016-11-19T18:01:18.642+02:00;What It’s Like To Live In Kiev After Marrying A Ukrainian Woman;"Suppose you are one of those adventurous Americans who meets and marries a beautiful foreign woman. You are the envy of all your friends. What next?
You can bring her back home to the United States or Europe. The guys will be jealous
column2: the women will feel threatened. And your bride will be a fish out of water—for a while. But it doesn’t take them long to get established. She will find a group of her countrywomen
column3: other Thais
column4: Vietnamese or Ukrainians. They will teach her the ropes. Where to go shopping for the kind of groceries she needs. The most efficient way to send money to her relatives back home. Where her fellow countrymen hang out. And
column5: oh yes! They will also learn American culture. Their friends will explain about American men and American divorce law. And that is where the trouble starts.

column1: My Vietnamese war bride
column2: an upscale Frenchified thing
column3: informed me after just over a year of marriage
column4: after I had helped her family escape Saigon
column5: that “A woman needs a man like a fish needs a bicycle.” When the inevitable the divorce came she refused a reasonable settlement offer and hired a junkyard dog lawyer to fight it in court. Losing
column6: she was shocked to discover that that offer was off the table.

column1: Keep your woman in her own country
column2: where she is comfortable and where the culture is more likely to appreciate men. You make the adjustment to her culture instead of vice versa. Why? American culture is about the most poisonous in the world. Almost anything is better. Countries that haven’t been indoctrinated in feminism and cultural Marxism still value children and respect a woman’s role in bearing them and raising them. They also respect a man’s role as the breadwinner and head of the family.

column1: I committed myself to Ukraine nine years ago
column2: met my wife seven years ago and our son appeared five years ago. It is worth enumerating the many ways in which it is a pleasure to be living with her and raising him in Kyiv instead of the USA.

column1: 1. Kyiv is a beautiful and lively city Beautiful architecture – Andreevska Church
Kyiv is a worthy capital city. It has millennium-long history studded with cathedrals and other exquisitely crafted monuments. There are many
column2: many targets for a tourist camera. The walled city was built to be defensible
column3: situated atop a steep bluff on the right bank of the Dnieper River close to where the Desno River joins from the east
column4: 20 miles south of where another major tributary
column5: the Pripyat
column6: flows in from the west. From their capital in Kyiv the Viking princes could easily sally out in their long boats to the Black Sea or anywhere in Western Russia.

column1: The sandy river beaches are good for swimming from June to September and for fishing any time it isn’t frozen. One can rent kayaks and rowboats or take a river cruise in the warmer months. When it does freeze it is dotted with ice fishermen. All it takes is a saw
column2: some bait
column3: a line and the anti-freeze of one’s choice. There are bicycle paths along the river and on the islands in the middle of the river. The city is experiencing a surge in the number of bicycle commuters.

column1: The Soviet system had its good points. They housed everybody in high-rise apartments. It may not be as attractive as detached houses
column2: but it makes for a very compact city. Those people needed places to breathe and exercise
column3: so the city is full of parks. As compact as Kyiv is
column4: it is
column5: with most people living in apartment blocks
column6: it easy to get around. Every place in the city is within walking distance of a convenience store of some sort
column7: and restaurants and shopping centers are usually within a walk or a short bus ride.

column1: Young people the world over want to live in the city
column2: and Kyiv is no exception. It has lots of bars
column3: cafés and nightclubs. The trends are toward sushi and Italian food. Ukraine is traditional enough that young people even go to church. There are Orthodox churches in every neighborhood
column4: and a handful of English-speaking congregations scattered throughout the city.

column1: Kyiv is home to Ukraine’s most famous universities
column2: Shevchenko University
column3: Kyiv-Mohyla Academy and Kyiv Polytechnic Institute. These are their Harvard
column4: Yale and MIT — an extraordinarily high percentage of business and government leaders have graduated from them. They know each other. As in the United States
column5: just being admitted to these universities is a sign of intelligence and talent. For a foreigner
column6: getting to know these elites is a lot easier than getting to know Ivy Leaguers in the United States.

column1: 2. Ukraine is extremely affordable Attractive
column2: inexpensive traditional markets (and supermarkets
column3: of course!)

column1: Kyiv is a very inexpensive place to live… very bottom of the Big Mac Index. The hryvnya exchange rate has fallen threefold since the start of the war in Donbass. Prices have risen
column2: especially for imports
column3: but not nearly as much. The tourist will note that it is still possible to get a decent hotel room for $30
column4: a taxi anywhere in the city for $10 and a meal for under $10. That is just the start.

column1: For those of us who live here
column2: 16¢ Metro rides—buses and trams are even less—make life cheap and convenient. Try the grocery store—10¢ a pound for potatoes
column3: beets
column4: carrots
column5: onions and cabbage
column6: the staples of the Ukrainian diet. Meat is generally under two dollars a pound. Although there is a lot of hue and cry about corruption in the energy business
column7: in the end it costs far less than in the United States: $100 a month to heat a house and between four and five dollars a gallon for gasoline. However
column8: most Ukrainians’ utilities are included in rent
column9: and only a few drive cars.

column1: Medical care is a preview of the impending Obamacare disaster. The state promises the moon but delivers only what it can afford. The average Ukrainian has to stand in a long line to get indifferent service from underequipped and underpaid doctors in shabby
column2: Soviet era hospitals. The flip side is that fee-for-service is alive and well. You can get decent care if you pay for it… and it doesn’t cost very much. In fact
column3: Ukraine is a medical tourism destination
column4: especially for fertility treatments
column5: plastic surgery and dental work.

column1: An American Social Security check makes you rich by local standards. It is a good place to live in retirement. Moreover
column2: any American can teach English
column3: and there are a number of entrepreneurial opportunities that don’t take a lot of capital to start.

column1: 3. Ukrainians are fairly uniformly Slavic – and they like people like themselves Just us Slavs
Western newspapers are full of horror stories about Ukraine — war and corruption. Leaders in Moscow
column2: Washington and Europe love to point fingers at us to distract from the increasingly blatant corruption surrounding those in the West. I’m no fan of corruption
column3: but given the fact that it is universal
column4: it is worth relating why Ukrainian corruption is more comfortable to live with than that of the Europe or the United States.

column1: There is no hypocrisy about our corruption. Or
column2: rather
column3: the hypocrisy is so transparent that nobody believes the lies. The virtue? We still have free speech. Ukrainians do not lose their jobs if they are politically incorrect. They are not jailed if they say what they think about Middle Eastern immigration. If you tell a woman she looks good
column4: she might actually blush and appreciate it.

column1: The corruption has kept the standard of living low
column2: which
column3: perversely
column4: has important benefits. People remain traditional because they have needed the support of families just to survive. “Asylum seeking” immigrants don’t come because there is nothing here for them—few jobs and nothing in the way of welfare.

column1: Not having immigrants leads to high levels of social capital. The people actually like and trust each other. I am the only American in our little development of 3000 homes. They have included me in the group—everybody knows me and says hello when I meet them on the street
column2: in the bus and in the stores. In my toney neighborhood of Bethesda
column3: Maryland
column4: most neighbors were too occupied with their important jobs to bother being neighborly.

column1: The fact that it is mostly just Slavs has a couple of important corollaries. There are no bad neighborhoods in Kyiv. People will tell you to avoid the Troyeshchena
column2: but a lot of people I know live there. I went to see for myself. I had a couple of pleasant shots of vodka chatting with the locals. I cannot imagine doing that in the Anacostia neighborhood of Washington DC.

column1: People always stand up to give my son and me a seat on the bus or Metro. Old ladies absolutely gush over him
column2: and engage him in small talk. They support their rising generation
column3: and are tickled to death that I am raising him to be a Ukrainian.

column1: Lastly
column2: even though the locals will tell you otherwise
column3: Ukrainians are good and polite drivers. They invariably stop for you at crosswalks. Very few will drive after even one drink. Fatalities per vehicle mile are about twice as high as in the West because the roads are poor
column4: but you can’t blame it on the drivers.

column1: 4. Young people have pride in themselves An English language Toastmasters meeting
Students and young professionals show self-restraint: no tattoos
column2: no piercings
column3: no sloppy clothes
column4: no swearing
column5: very little smoking and no drugs. They are what in the 1950s was called square—delightfully so. They look forward to marriage and families
column6: especially the women. For this reason they are perhaps not as easy as girls elsewhere
column7: but when you get one
column8: you have something of substance.

column1: There are lots of places to meet young people. Needless to say
column2: bars and nightclubs. There are studios all over town giving inexpensive dance lessons—salsa and swing are big—and hundreds of sports clubs. The English language Mafia club is thriving. The Toastmasters public speaking club attracts many of the best and brightest with meetings in English
column3: German
column4: Russian and Ukrainian. The Language Exchange club also meets in several languages. From May to September
column5: the river beaches are great
column6: surrounded by restaurants
column7: bars and discos.

column1: Ukrainians love to practice their English and welcome foreigners. Not too many make it this far east. It is an easy place to make friends.
5. It is a good place to sit out the West’s coming civil unrest One of Kyiv’s many lovely river beaches
The Western press would have you believe that Kyiv is a lawless Wild West. That is the opposite from the truth — even today it is safer than any Western capital city.

The first danger cited is Vladimir Putin. When are the Russians going to invade? Answer: they won’t. Throughout is history Russia has expanded by stealth and opportunity. They stopped when Finland fought back in 1939 and Georgia fought back in 2008. They swiped the Baltics and part of Poland only after Germany had started a war that diverted the world’s attention. They imposed their will on their European satellites only because the Red Army conveniently occupied them at the end of World War II.
In Ukraine
column2: they took the opportunity of political chaos in 2014 to steal Crimea
column3: where by treaty they already had a large military presence. Emboldened
column4: they thought they had an opportunity in the Russian-speaking Donbass. But the Ukrainians resisted
column5: and that war is at a standstill. Putin knows full well that 80 million ethnic Russians cannot dominate 40 million ethnic Ukrainians
column6: especially under the glare of world opinion. Despite what the neocons may have shouted to sway the US election
column7: the Russians are not coming. Another comforting thought is that there is nothing here worth nuking. It is a benefit of staying out of NATO.

column1: There is no dependent class here to rise up when economic hardship hits. Hardship is already here. There are no discontented minorities. Gypsies
column2: the most visible of them
column3: actually work—they sell flowers and work as junk dealers. You cannot be a parasite if there is no blood to suck. It is the United States and Europe that have legions of restless unemployed who are only being pacified by government benefits. and will rise up when governments can no longer afford them.

column1: Ukraine’s corruption is well understood by everybody. As much as they complain
column2: people know how to cope with it. It may take bribery to get things done
column3: but they generally do get done. Corruption does not result in much violence. Occasionally some hard-nosed judge or a pesky reporter gets bumped off
column4: true
column5: but in every case the victim could have explained quite clearly why he was targeted. It is not like the random killing of whites by blacks in the United States or random Islamic terror in Western Europe.

column1: Ukraine has lots of land
column2: excellent agriculture
column3: abundant water
column4: reasonably good natural resources
column5: and a homogeneous and hard-working population. It is not as dependent on international trade as most European countries. When the world financial system collapses
column6: Ukraine will come through looking pretty good. They are so far down that it all looks like up
column7: and the stress lines for civil unrest simply don’t exist. Though you may come here for the love of a wonderful woman
column8: you will find it a delightful place to make your home.

column1: Read More: Ukrainian Girls Have Lost Their Love For American Men

column4: NessTheNomad.com . November 21
column5: 2016 Lifestyle

column1: Have you ever had a curiosity in photography
column2: yet you weren’t sure if it’s a hobby really worthy of your limited time? Then this article was written for you
column3: as I was also once in your shoes.

column1: I picked up a DSLR camera for the first time back in 2013
column2: which awoke a passion inside me that I never even knew was there. Three and half years later
column3: I’m here to tell you just a few of the many benefits and realizations I’ve experienced by taking on this timeless hobby. Here are eight reasons photography might just be the most meaningful hobby you’ve overlooked your entire life. 1. An Opportunity to Flex Your Creative Muscle

column1: In order to be balanced human beings
column2: I believe people need to be physically healthy
column3: spiritually awake
column4: and creatively expressive. Photography
column5: just like writing and film
column6: is a selfless way to be creative while also giving something back to the world.

column1: The way we interpret our world changes from individual to individual
column2: and photography provides a medium for people to express themselves. Ask ten different photographers to photograph the same thing – a city for example – and be prepared to see ten wildly different visions of the same subject. In our sensory-overload world
column3: it feels good to create something that’s uniquely you. 2. Appreciate and Understand Your Surroundings More

column1: I now find myself seeing everything around me in rectangular frames–a takeaway from having to frame so many pictures over the years. “Oh
column2: those people over there would fit perfectly into a 3:2 box
column3: ” or “that building over there would look perfect boxed in from this angle.” My eyes are now sharper than ever.

column1: But I also find myself observing and appreciating all the little things around me. I always have to keep my camera nearby
column2: because I often want to photograph something I’ve noticed in my daily routine. The pattern on a sewer lid
column3: a reflection in a puddle
column4: birds perched in a tree
column5: and so forth.

column1: My pre-photographer self
column2: just like most of the rest of the world
column3: would have walked right past these things without a care in the world. Yet now I can be entertained from the most minuscule and simple things
column4: especially if my camera is handy. The world is full of photogenic things
column5: if can just teach yourself to notice them. 3. Help Preserve History

column1: Since its inception
column2: photography has always been one of the most moving ways to preserve history in our rapidly changing modern times. Photos touch people in a way other media can’t. Both photography and video are both visual arts
column3: but photographs differ in that they capture merely one frame of what is going on. Yet one frame is all one needs to feel taken back to another time.

column1: With the advent of the smartphone
column2: photography is as accessible as ever. While this sounds good on paper
column3: the truth is our world’s becoming more and more flooded with garbage and narcissistic photographs. Our world needs more adventurous and well-trained photographers out there taking photos of the modern world we live in and the rapid changes it’s undergoing. These are the photos that will be cherished decades down the road
column4: not all the shitty selfies that bog down social media. 4. Travel Experiences Will Be More Meaningful

column1: Photography goes with traveling like bread goes with butter. It took me nearly five years of traveling internationally to finally get serious about doing photography on my trips
column2: and after I got started
column3: I never looked back.

column1: Rather than traveling for escapism and hedonism
column2: I’m traveling to learn about and document our world. As a result
column3: my trips feel much more meaningful and fulfilling than they ever did before. The way you see and come to understand a country as a photographer is quite different than if you weren’t one.

column1: I now divide my history of travel experiences into two separate groups–the trips I had before I owned a DSLR camera
column2: and the trips I had after buying one. Photography is so fun and addicting
column3: that I find myself wanting to go back to all those pre-DSLR camera destinations
column4: even the ones I didn’t enjoy all that much
column5: just so I can re-experience them with a camera in hand. 5. An Opportunity to Meet New People

column1: One thing I always try to do when I travel is meet fellow photographers. Whether they be foreign or local
column2: I appreciate talking to people with an observational eye
column3: as they can provide me with unique insight that non-photographers rarely can.

column1: But photography doesn’t just help you meet other photographers
column2: it helps you meet other people from all walks of life. I’ve had regular people on the street come up and talk to me once they saw I was taking photos. I’ve also met people from online for no other reason than they liked my work.

column1: Being a good photographer can also be a great way to meet women. They’re not gonna start blowing you as soon as they see your awesome pictures
column2: but don’t be surprised if you discover some newfound female admiration once your excellent photography skills are out in the open. And if you can make a woman look beautiful in a photo
column3: she’ll admire you in a way you never imagined. 6. A Blog with an Edge

column1: In the diverse world of independently run blogs
column2: how many bloggers do you know who can both write well and photograph well? I can literally only think of one
column3: and the fact that this blogger is just as good at utilizing a camera as he is at wielding a pen (or rather a keyboard)
column4: puts his website in a league of its own in terms of quality content.

column1: Though I still highly respect the good bloggers out there for their amazing writing skills and insights
column2: I think they’re doing both their readers and websites a great disservice by merely using stock photos or shitty shot-with-a-cell-phone photos in their articles.

column1: Readers can definitely tell the difference when a blogger takes all of their own photos with a nice DSLR camera. Start taking nice
column2: DSLR-shot photos and see for yourself how they can enhance your articles. They’ll give you just that much more of an edge over all the other bloggers who don’t. 7. You’ll Also Have an Edge over 98% of Others on Social Media and Dating Sites

column1: Since everyone else is posting lame
column2: smartphone-taken shots all over their social media accounts
column3: your DSLR-shot photos could shine like diamonds in the rough. The same way you stand above 98% of other men by lifting weights regularly
column4: the same advantage can be expected by not taking cheap shortcuts with your social media-bound photography. Your Facebook
column5: Instagram
column6: and Twitter accounts will all look better than ever before.

column1: This is also true for dating websites and apps
column2: where most chumps just take some lame mirror selfies with their smartphone and then upload them to their accounts. Dudes with well-taken
column3: nontraditional photos stand out big time. Don’t just take my word for it
column4: as there has actually been plenty of discussion about these benefits over at the Roosh V Forum .

column1: And although they can be very helpful
column2: you don’t actually need another photographer with you to get some good shots of yourself. Rather all you need is your camera
column3: an autofocus lens
column4: a tripod
column5: a remote shutter
column6: and a creative eye. 8. A Resume-enhancing
column7: Marketable Skill

column1: Photography isn’t just mentally rewarding
column2: it can also be financially rewarding if you play your cards right. The field of profitable photography may be vast and highly competitive
column3: but one thing’s for sure – the demand for new photographs is infinite. The world never stops turning after all. Stock
column4: portrait
column5: wedding
column6: wildlife
column7: travel
column8: sports
column9: and news photography are just a few of the most in demand and profitable niches.

column1: But if you really wanna make money selling your photographs
column2: you gotta make a name for yourself by sharpening your skills and networking with the right people. A great photographer who no one knows exists won’t make any money.

column1: My father is an outdoorsman slash wildlife photographer with decades of experience
column2: tens of thousands of photos
column3: and a giant network of contacts from his industry. It seems like magazine and website editors are always knocking on his door
column4: because they know he probably has a nice shot of exactly what they’re looking for. Often all he has to do is dig through his archives
column5: and boom–he’s made 500 bucks. Conclusion

column1: Stop dreaming about it
column2: and just give photography a shot already. Borrow your friend or a family member’s DSLR camera for the weekend
column3: and just get out there and take pictures of anything that strikes your fancy.

column1: Photography takes decades to master
column2: but it all begins with a single click of the shutter button. Yet sometimes all it takes is one little click to realize you’ve been missing out on something very big and meaningful your entire life. You’ll never know until you try.";english;2016-11-21T23:57:51.289+02:00;returnofkings.com;US;25945.0;8 Reasons Why You Should Try Photography As A Hobby;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;hate

column1: 8033;f36b6b9d1bc37888ca4c3efe57ea1e302c9c92a9;0;David G. Brown;2016-11-22T23:03:06.646+02:00;Stockholm’s “Feminist” Snow Removal Program Causes The Entire City To Shut Down;"Convinced that previous snow plowing policies were “sexist
column2: ” the city government of the Swedish capital of Stockholm recently implemented a “feminist” system for clearing it. It ended in disaster and the city came to an absolute standstill. For a start
column3: four times as many people than usual were hospitalized for snow-related injuries. Nearly as importantly
column4: countless workers
column5: most of them men
column6: were prevented from getting to work. It would appear that the patriarchy-backed snow won
column7: as local politicians ended up apologizing for the havoc-causing changes.

column1: Havoc like this:
Forgetting that motor vehicles are often more impeded by snow than pedestrians (and create a greater safety risk)
column2: municipal resources
column3: which had already been increased
column4: were diverted to clearing bicycle paths and sidewalks and away from main roads. Areas like schools were also prioritized
column5: which again ignores the frequently greater ease of walking in snow than driving in it
column6: plus the longer distances car commuters face compared to children
column7: mothers and other women walking to places. The situation is quite plainly moronic for a further reason: non-main roads and other parts of a city take up much more space
column8: meaning that the Swedish capital’s snow removal teams were targeting a far larger
column9: less densely used zone. To boot
column10: this was all during a November already breaking records for snowfall .

column1: The saga in Stockholm reads like an microcosm of feminism itself: an over-educated (meaning under-educated) group of leftists come together
column2: create “data” based on feelings
column3: and produce a plan of action that screws up an entire community. Feminists in Stockholm had previously complained that the thoroughfares cleaned up first and most extensively by snowplows were the ones heavily used by men. How they came to this conclusion is unclear but
column4: given the shutdown of the city that resulted from the feminist changes
column5: it wasn’t based on any solid reasoning. With private cars and public transport vehicles alike unable to move in many cases
column6: the “female-friendly” snow-clearing ended up adversely impacting far more people
column7: including women
column8: than the old one.

column1: Well done
column2: feminists and white knights.

column1: What this says about Sweden Is it really surprising that one of the people responsible for Stockholm’s “female-friendly” snow plowing scandal
column2: Mayor Karin Wanngård
column3: is a feminist and career politician who first joined the council in her teens?

column1: Because Sweden is perhaps the most concentrated welfare state in the world
column2: not having people at their jobs and instead stuck in snow is a very bad thing. How can a country continue to pay such a large bill for handouts with elected representatives of the caliber of Stockholm’s trying to ruin things? Sweden is also home to a growing class of low-skilled migrant communities
column3: including many tens of thousands from the most recent Mediterranean waves last year. Its recent migrant population is now essentially the same proportionally-speaking as states more typically associated with multiculturalism
column4: such as Canada and Australia. And non-ethnic Swedes in Sweden tend to come from more troublesome cultures
column5: compared to the more assimilation-friendly East Asians and Indians emigrating to Canada and Australia.

column1: How Sweden intends to deal with issues like this while balancing urgent economic needs remains to be seen
column2: especially with brain-dead initiatives like the snow plow fiasco taking precedence. Add to the mix the recent creation of a “mansplaining” hotline by a Swedish labor union and you start to see the “real” problems Scandinavia’s most basketcase society is trying to solve.

column1: So who was organizing the snow plowing–and actually doing it? Yup
column2: you guessed it
column3: it’s a man driving.

column1: There’s no doubt that the feminist snow plowing scheme was an unmitigated disaster. And it’s also extremely likely that the vast majority of people tasked with clearing Stockholm’s streets are men. Oh
column2: the irony. Not only do feminist politicians try to preference women in the removal of snow
column3: they expect men to do the work in achieving it. Just as sanitation workers and garbage collectors are invariably male
column4: don’t expect to catch too many female snowplow operators and other snow-clearing employees in Stockholm.

column1: Wake up
column2: Sweden Swedish multiculturalism in action.

column1: Stockholm’s snow removal catastrophe is emblematic of a country refusing to deal with its real malaise. While the men who built Sweden are categorized as would-be oppressors
column2: Swedish society itself is close to breaking point. Even Stockholm’s central train station is now terribly unsafe and various city police forces have long made it known that they do not have control of many suburbs. In particular
column3: Malmö
column4: Sweden’s third city
column5: and certain districts of Stockholm are notorious for ethnic ghettos
column6: gang violence
column7: rape
column8: and other crime.

column1: But no
column2: mansplaining hotlines and not removing snow in a new
column3: feminist way are the clear and present dangers most Swedes should fear at night.

8038;efa576cbe50d9fcd26e80c0e1ec80b70f8b42b33;0;Beau Albrecht;2016-11-25T00:07:57.204+02:00;The Ugly Truth Of Six More Leftist “Heroes”;"Earlier I skewered nine dictators

column4: and politicians adored by leftists despite considerable failings in policy
column5: ethics
column6: and hygiene. Here are six more over-hyped figures revered by leftists who always get everything wrong.

column1: Franklin Delano Roosevelt
How the world remembers: FDR led America through the Great Depression and WWII
column2: remembered fondly by seniors who heard his inspiring fireside chats.

column1: The ugly truth: Some economists argue that FDR’s measures prolonged the Great Depression . All the New Deal programs were struck down as unconstitutional
column2: except Social Security. He got the Supreme Court to back off by threatening to pack the Court with more members with views to his liking. That restrained their judicial opinion
column3: though the Constitution doesn’t grant Congress the power to create a Federal retirement system.

column1: Social Security works—though it’s slim pickings if it’s a retiree’s only income—and for decades the surplus has been a cash cow offsetting Congressional overspending . However
column2: the aging Baby Boomers who didn’t have enough children might turn the cash cow into an albatross. Further
column3: the Social Security Number is now a de-facto universal ID number; a convenient database field for monitoring citizens . America’s Founding Fathers would have been appalled at today’s domestic spying
column4: and the Soviet dictators of old would have wept with envy.

column1: FDR pledged to keep the USA out of WWII . Meanwhile
column2: he quietly did everything possible to antagonize Japan
column3: a once-friendly nation
column4: such as (among several items) freezing their assets and cutting off their oil supply. When he got intelligence of the upcoming attack on Pearl Harbor
column5: he didn’t order the base to be locked and loaded.

column1: If that wasn’t bad enough: So nearly a quarter million Americans died in battle
column2: but at least the pivotal intervention came just in time to “make the world safe for democracy”
column3: right? Unfortunately
column4: FDR was far too friendly with the USSR
column5: giving them nearly $11 billion in food
column6: weaponry
column7: and other supplies (about $119 billion adjusted for inflation).

column1: At the Yalta conference
column2: FDR agreed to let “Uncle Joe” Stalin take over Eastern Europe. General Patton wanted to press forward at full speed to keep as much territory as possible away from Soviet tyranny
column3: but politics hampered him every step of the way until he got rubbed out . When the Iron Curtain rose and the Cold War began
column4: Winston Churchill said
column5: “We slaughtered the wrong pig.” If only Roosevelt had listened to his generals!

column1: FDR wasn’t a Communist
column2: but many of his appointees and trusted advisers were. Later
column3: Joseph McCarthy barely scratched the surface trying to get rid of them.

column1: Walter Cronkite
How the world remembers: He was a long-time CBS anchorman
column2: reporting many triumphs and tragedies. A friendly face on living room TVs for decades
column3: he became everyone’s “Uncle Walter”. According to polls
column4: he was the “most trusted man in America”.

column1: The ugly truth: Although a decent fellow in person
column2: Cronkite was the archetypal big-name liberal journalist
column3: spinning the news for decades. Sometimes it was rather subliminal
column4: including his signature subtle sneer. Most of the public then believed journalists were muckrakers and unbiased truth-tellers; as Cronkite’s tagline went
column5: “And that’s the way it is.”

column1: Until Cronkite’s late career
column2: the mainstream media had a veneer of respectability—perhaps like warped plastic barely sticking to crumbling particleboard
column3: but a veneer nonetheless. There once were only three American corporate TV networks. From Manhattan
column4: they were the public’s information gatekeepers; no other broadcast news (besides shortwave radio) was available. Baby Boomer liberals might get a bit misty-eyed remembering those days. Today
column5: six mega-conglomerates own 90% of the media
column6: but at least the Internet lets us present our own perspectives and call out biased reporters .

column1: If that wasn’t bad enough : His biggest whopper was about the Tet Offensive. The Viet Cong launched a desperate all-out assault
column2: suffered very heavy losses
column3: mostly it was over within a day
column4: and ultimately the VC gained no territory. However
column5: “the most trusted man in America” gave them a propaganda victory
column6: reporting that the Vietnam War was hopeless. Public opinion promptly turned against the war. Ho Chi Minh should’ve given Cronkite a medal
column7: an honorary VC generalship
column8: and a dozen roses.

column1: Many forget that the 1973 Paris Accords brought peace. Two years later
column2: though
column3: the shaky Ford administration couldn’t persuade Congress to respond appropriately to a Shit Test by North Vietnam. Then they invaded
column4: and Saigon fell. All that’s a long story
column5: but public opinion from biased reporting certainly didn’t help. That affected America’s prestige abroad
column6: along with the lives of millions of South Vietnamese killed or sent to “reeducation camps” .

column3: believed the hype and didn’t read it

Even overlooking the lunacy

column4: dewier

column1: The media usually portrays pickup artists as reprobates

column1: Ted Kennedy Best friends forever
column2: east and west

column1: How the world remembers: He was “the Lion of the Senate”
column2: representing Massachusetts from 1962 until his death in 2009. This champion of social justice carried on the Kennedy legacy—hailed as America’s nobility—after his two brothers were tragically slain.

column1: The ugly truth: He was as passionate for booze and adultery as he was for social justice
column2: but the suckers kept reelecting him. His lack of character sank way deeper
column3: though; all the way underwater.

column1: After a night of partying on Chappaquiddick Island
column2: Ted Kennedy drove off a bridge. He escaped
column3: but failed to help his passenger
column4: Mary Jo Kopechne. Per one of the investigators
column5: she suffocated slowly in an air pocket for about two hours. If he’d ran to a nearby house for help—rather than waiting nine hours to sober up—she would’ve survived. He got a two month suspended sentence
column6: barely a slap on the wrist for vehicular manslaughter. The judge basically said poor Teddy had suffered enough. (What about how Miss Kopechne suffered?) There’s one set of rules for the elites
column7: and another for us. Shortly thereafter
column8: he tried to spin-doctor it with a “woe is me” shtick. The suckers kept reelecting him
column9: though a Presidential bid was now beyond reach.

column1: As for his many legislative actions
column2: the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965 was the most notorious. He promised the public :

column1: First
column2: our cities will not be flooded with a million immigrants annually. Under the proposed bill
column3: the present level of immigration remains substantially the same… Secondly
column4: the ethnic mix of this country will not be upset… Contrary to the charges in some quarters
column5: [the bill] will not inundate America with immigrants from any one country or area
column6: or the most populated and deprived nations of Africa and Asia…. In the final analysis
column7: the ethnic pattern of immigration under the proposed measure is not expected to change as sharply as the critics seem to think… The bill will not flood our cities with immigrants. It will not upset the ethnic mix of our society. It will not relax the standards of admission. It will not cause American workers to lose their jobs .

column1: The “Lion of the Senate” was lyin’ his fat ass off! This population replacement policy threatens America’s future
column2: just as the Coudenhove-Kalergi Plan is doing in Europe. Still
column3: the suckers kept reelecting him.

column1: If that wasn’t bad enough: Besides giving away the country to which the Constitution granted “the Blessings of Liberty to ourselves and our Posterity “
column2: Lyin’ Ted was in cahoots with the KGB . He proposed to help his Soviet pal Yuri Andropov with tidying up the USSR’s image problem during the Cold War’s endgame. The damning documents suggested that Walter Cronkite (see above) and Barbara Walters might be used for this effort. Conservatives often suspect liberals are soft on Communism; little did they know how cozy Ted Kennedy was in bed with Comrade Andropov.

column1: John Lennon
How the world remembers: He was a talented musician
column2: arguably the most prominent of the Beatles. Their story was an archetypal garage band becoming a bar band and eventually breaking out into great fame. Lennon produced dozens of hits that still get air play. He’s remembered as a wonderful man
column3: an embodiment of the 1960s (the good parts
column4: anyway)
column5: and the conscience of the world.

column1: The ugly truth: Despite Lennon’s considerable talents
column2: not all his songs were excellent. Things slipped with the White Album . (“Revolution 9”
column3: really?) After the Beatles broke up
column4: he started a solo career
column5: often featuring songs with sophomoric political poses. His last album produced during his life—after dragging himself out of a long heroin stupor—was Double Fantasy . Critics at first agreed that it sucked. After a nut shot Lennon
column6: they felt sorry for him and declared it brilliant.

column1: Lennon was the archetypal leftist celebrity using fame to push politics. Granted
column2: everyone has a right to their opinion
column3: but being able to sing or act confers no special political expertise. His song “Imagine” is particularly telling. As he put it:

column1: Imagine that there was no more religion
column2: no more country
column3: no more politics
column4: ’ is virtually the Communist Manifesto
column5: even though I’m not particularly a Communist and I do not belong to any movement.

column1: Being under the shadow of the Berlin Wall back in their bar gig days should’ve precluded sophomoric posturing like this.
If that wasn’t bad enough: His failings are quite troubling
column2: too numerous to fully detail. One item is abandoning his family the way his own father did. A truly wonderful man wouldn’t do that.

column1: Another item was his extensive substance abuse. He spent 1974 guzzling booze
column2: his “lost weekend”. One night
column3: a waitress refused service because he stuck a menstrual pad on his head. Then:

column1: Lennon: “Do you know who I am?”
Waitress: “Yeah
column2: you’re some asshole with a Kotex on his forehead.”

column1: One Lennon biographer asked Timothy Leary
column2: who’d been on hundreds of acid trips
column3: what Lennon’s extreme LSD consumption would do. Leary had no idea! Finally
column4: what kind of inner vacuum caused this highly successful musician
column5: much beloved by the public
column6: to get himself strung out on heroin?

column1: Jimmy Carter In this heart-warming scene
column2: Jimmy Carter and Uncle Fidel stand for the Cuban national anthem in Havana

column1: How the world remembers: Carter is praised as a rare honest politician
column2: exemplifying Christian principles and tolerance.

column1: The ugly truth: The economy tanked during the Carter administration: double-digit inflation and high unemployment. Economists are still puzzled by stagflation; normally
column2: unemployment and inflation are inversely correlated. At least Obama gave economists another data point to study.

column1: Carter’s commendably not corrupt
column2: but exemplified bleeding-hearted liberalism. Despite winning the Nobel Peace Prize for not being George W. Bush (likewise Al Gore and The Lightworker)
column3: Carter was a lackluster embarrassment. He was known for TMI statements
column4: for example about his hemorrhoids and committing adultery in his heart (at least Clinton had the balls to do it for real). He ranked lower than Mr. Whipple on a face recognition survey. The Boston Globe reported on one of his speeches with the headline “More Mush From the Wimp”; finally journalists got something right.

column1: Carter’s shining foreign policy moment was the Camp David Accords
column2: establishing peace between Egypt and Israel. America started giving over a billion annually to each party for making peace
column3: which ironically supplies their military. Why? The USA wasn’t even a combatant
column4: aside from the USS Liberty incident which certainly shouldn’t inspire American tribute money. Taxpayers still fund this absurd protection racket.

column1: Worse
column2: he badly bungled the Iran hostage crisis. One Iranian official later stated they would’ve released the hostages if the USA had threatened force in the beginning. Yep
column3: Carter failed Iran’s Shit Test. Consequentially
column4: the USA lost tons of international prestige
column5: and the ordeal of the hostages dragged on unnecessarily.

column1: If that wasn’t bad enough: Carter is often a little too cordial with notorious dictators . Worse
column2: Clinton trusted him to represent the USA during disarmament talks with North Korea. They gave him the Potemkin village show; he bought it hook
column3: line
column4: and sinker. Yet again
column5: Carter was played for a chump—the USA opened its wallet and gave North Korea aid
column6: and they pinky-swore to stop their nuclear program. Now the Norks have nukes—surprise! Awesome job
column7: Mister Nice Guy!

column1: A Hillary Clinton-supporting advocacy organization had no trouble accepting a $20
column2: 000 donation funneled through a Belize bank to use in this year’s presidential election campaign – until its decision was about to be made public in a series of undercover videos by James O’Keefe’s Project Veritas Action.

column1: Suddenly
column2: the head of the organization expressed suspicion about the donation’s overseas origin and decided to return it.

column1: That’s one of the significant revelations in the latest in a series of videos released by O’Keefe called “Rigging the Election.”
O’Keefe explained he had a fictitious donor meet with Bob Creamer
column2: who was a staffer at Americans United for Change
column3: a group supporting Clinton for president
column4: until the videos started appearing last week.

column1: He said Creamer
column2: who boasted of working directly for the Clinton campaign
column3: directed that the $20
column4: 000 donation go to AUFC “to disrupt rallies and fund bracketing ops.”

column1: O’Keefe said he and his colleagues were very careful not to violate the law themselves.
Creamer was clear about his ties to Clinton
column2: stating
column3: “Every morning I am on a call at 10:30 that goes over the message being driven by the campaign headquarters.”

column1: Sign the precedent-setting petition supporting Trump’s call for an independent prosecutor to investigate Hillary Clinton!

Project Veritas’ first video explained how the Clinton campaign uses “hidden connections” to incite violence at Donald Trump rallies. Its second video showed plans for step-by-step voter fraud and the third exposed “prohibited communications” between Hillary Clinton’s campaign
column2: “the DNC and the nonprofit Americans United for Change.”

column1: The fourth video “breaks down the process of the long-term investigation.” It comes after Creamer’s announcement that he was stepping down from campaign responsibilities.
O’Keefe and Project Veritas Action have filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission.
Among the revelations in the latest video was Creamer was boasting of his close links to President Obama.
“Oh
column2: Barack Obama’s was the best campaign in the history of American politics
column3: I mean the second one
column4: I mean the first was good
column5: too. I was a consultant to both
column6: the second one
column7: was everything hit on every level and every aspect
column8: ” he said. “He’s a pro
column9: I’ve known the president since he was a community organizer in Chicago.”

column1: When asked whether a potential donor could meet Obama
column2: Creamer said: “OK
column3: you may have a lot more opportunity once he is done in 98 days
column4: 97. I was just at an event with him in Chicago
column5: Friday of last week
column6: he is just as good as ever. I do a lot of work with the White House on their issues
column7: helping to run issued campaigns that they have been involved in. I mean
column8: for immigration reform for the … the health care bill
column9: trying to make America more like Britain when it comes to gun violence issues.”

column1: Explained Project Veritas: “The more that was promised to Creamer

column4: Scott Foval
column5: Jenna Price from the DNC

column8: as seen in the three previous PVA videos.”

column1: In the first video
column2: Foval

column1: “ I feel strongly that the Supreme Court needs to stand on the side of the American people
column2: not on the side of the powerful corporations and the wealthy. For me
column3: that means that we need a Supreme Court that will stand up on behalf of women’s rights
column4: on behalf of the rights of the LGBT community
column5: that will stand up and say no to Citizens United
column6: a decision that has undermined the election system in our country because of the way it permits dark
column7: unaccountable money to come into our electoral system. ”

column1: – Hillary Clinton
The first salvo from Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton (or rather
column2: her answer to the first question posed by Fox News’ Chris Wallace to her and Donald Trump at the third presidential debate) was as chilling as it was an exemplar of hypocrisy.

column1: Those on the left are quite fond of leveling the accusation against conservatives of employing “dog whistle politics
column2: ” rhetoric that allegedly contains hidden or esoteric derogatory messaging which targets a specific subgroup within the opposition. Ms. Clinton’s response to Wallace’s question (where they wanted to see the Supreme Court take the country
column3: and their views on how the Constitution ought to be interpreted) however
column4: was representative of this tactic.

column1: While women’s rights and those of the LGBT community may seem to be a curious focus for the high court (since objectively
column2: women wouldn’t appear to be particularly oppressed given that one has been nominated to run for president
column3: and the LGBT community accounts for less than 5 percent of the American population)
column4: Clinton’s answer revealed the focus she believes the court should have once she becomes empress.

column1: “Women’s rights” is of course “dog whistle” for unfettered abortion
column2: even late-term abortion
column3: which is essentially infanticide via dismemberment. “LGBT rights” is “dog whistle” for disenfranchising the majority of Americans who hold traditional values
column4: primarily Christians. Leveraging a vocal minority of homosexuals
column5: bisexuals and transgender individuals whom the left has whipped into a froth against Christians is the methodology that was employed to negate the political power of Christians in Europe and Canada. A direct assault via legislation in this area would not work in the U.S. (at least not at present); however
column6: judicial rulings could effectively bring about the same result.

column1: Let us leave aside for a moment the fact that judicial activism is unethical and skirts the Constitution and that Clinton’s overall objectives are manifestly evil. Hillary Clinton’s stated priorities for the Supreme Court are a clear indicator of her desire to use the court as a bludgeon against the Constitution and individual liberties
column2: rather than allowing it to perform its designated function. The hypocrisy attendant to Clinton citing the rights of women and homosexuals when she is beholden via financial contributions to nations that institutionally persecute and murder members of these groups remains plain for all to see
column3: despite being conveniently ignored by the press.

column1: Clinton’s reference to “powerful corporations and the wealthy” and the malign influence of that sinister conservative organization
column2: Citizens United
column3: was of course another exercise in blatant hypocrisy. Clinton is quite wealthy
column4: and corrupt or otherwise compromised powerful corporations have been instrumental in bringing about the designs of American socialists. Even if Citizens United were a vehicle for “dark
column5: unaccountable money
column6: ” the scope of its influence would pale next to the subversive designs of the Muslim Brotherhood
column7: with which Bill and Hillary Clinton have been partnered for decades
column8: or the myriad tentacles of organizations funded by George Soros
column9: the former Nazi collaborator dedicated to advancing oligarchical collectivism in America
column10: someone with whom the Clintons also have a long association.

column1: One need not attempt to decipher the thinly veiled intent behind Clinton’s debate rhetoric to discern what a Hillary Clinton presidency might look like. Her actions to date – and particularly those in the pursuit of seeking that office – should suffice quite nicely. Despite the craven complicity of the establishment press (mainstream media)
column2: there is ample evidence for even the most indolent news consumer to reach the conclusion that she and the Democratic leviathan supporting her
column3: and which facilitated Barack Obama’s rise to power
column4: are fundamentally malignant.

column1: In recent days
column2: we’ve become aware of all manner of unethical conspiracies and outright criminality that’s been brought to bear in getting Clinton elected
column3: from Democratic officials tampering with the outcome of the illegal email server investigation
column4: to the oversampling of key demographics in polling in order to enhance the public perception of Clinton’s popularity
column5: to the recent revelation of criminally prosecutable actions on the part of the Clinton campaign
column6: the Democratic National Committee and the White House.

column1: The bottom line here is that Hillary Clinton represents a class of people who transcend even the loathed archetypal modern politician in their rapaciousness and amorality. What all Americans – not just voters
column2: and not just Republicans – need to realize is that leaders at the highest levels in the Republican Party are every bit as culpable as the gutter operatives of the Democratic Party who pay miscreants to dress up as ducks
column3: instigate fistfights at opposition rallies and
column4: yes
column5: even vote for their candidates.

column1: The burning question is this: In the end
column2: are we to be governed by the will of the people
column3: or are we going to continue pretending that we have a representative government
column4: when we are in effect being ruled by abject thugs operating behind a faux veneer of government?

column1: 12636;8b68a43f03985d72a1f076823c749579436b1ee4;0;Jerome R. Corsi;2016-10-27T03:04:37.085+03:00;YouTube bans 'Clinton's black son';"Print Side-by-side of Bill Clinton and Danney Williams
NEW YORK –YouTube on Wednesday suspended the account of Danney Williams
column2: the 30-year-old who has claimed since the 1990s to be the black son of former President Bill Clinton.

column1: YouTube
column2: citing “repeated or severe violations of our Terms of Use and/or Community Guidelines
column3: ” declared the account “cannot be restored.”

column1: The YouTube decision blocked the nine-minute feature “BANISHED – The Untold Story of Danney Williams
column2: ” which had received 1.2 million views since Williams posted it last week. Produced by filmmaker Joel Gilbert
column3: it drew nearly 100
column4: 000 views per day and more than 1
column5: 000 viewer comments
column6: with the overwhelming majority expressing support for Williams and outrage at the Clintons for not being willing to allow a DNA test to determine paternity.

column1: Like the reporting you see here? Sign up for free news alerts from WND.com
column2: America’s independent news network.

column1: “My YouTube account has been deleted
column2: but the same video appears in 50 other places on YouTube alone
column3: ” Williams said on his Facebook page after being notified of YouTube’s decision. “[YouTube] can’t handle the truth! Please share #BillClintonSon.”

column1: Twitter also continues to allow Williams to post the “Banished” video on Danney Williams’ page
column2: but the Twitter link to YouTube displays the message : “This video is no longer available because the YouTube account associated with this video has been terminated. Sorry about that.”

column1: The video is still running on Danney Williams-Clinton’s Facebook page
column2: as well as on the YouTube channel operated by Gilbert.

column1: Attempt to silence Danney Williams?
Gilbert told WND he helped Williams file an online appeal form on YouTube asking why the account was suspended and demanding it be immediately reinstated.
“The behavior of YouTube/Google in suspending Danney’s account is outrageous! There have been absolutely zero violations of any kind let alone a severe one of any YouTube terms or guidelines
column2: ” Gilbert said.

column1: Gilbert was outspoken in charging YouTube with partisan political motives for the suspension.
“The only possible explanation is that the Clinton campaign requested YouTube/Google to silence Danney
column2: ‘to run him off the plantation’ as Danney said Hillary Clinton did to him and his aunt when he was a small child and they were chased off the grounds of the Arkansas governor’s mansion in 1990
column3: ” Gilbert said.

column1: “Danney cannot be silenced any longer
column2: ” he continued. “Hillary may try to sweep Danney Williams under the rug
column3: but it’s not going to work this time. His story is out there
column4: and every day more and more people understand Bill and Hillary Clinton banished this young man from their family because of the color of his skin.”

column1: See the Danney Williams video feature:
WND reported Oct. 19 that in the hours before the third and final presidential debate
column2: attorneys for Williams were in Las Vegas to announce their intention to file a paternity suit demanding DNA evidence from the former president.

column1: Accompanying the dramatic announcement was a rap music video celebrating Williams that went viral on the Internet.
No definitive DNA test
WND reported that no DNA test was conducted in 1999
column2: despite media reports to the contrary when Williams’ claim first surfaced.

column1: Clinton defenders since 1999 have contended the tabloid Star Magazine conducted a “DNA showdown” proving Bill Clinton was not Williams’ father
column2: citing Star Magazine editor Phil Bunton saying at the time
column3: “There was no match
column4: nothing even close.”

column1: But in an interview
column2: Bunton told WND that no blood sample was obtained from Clinton and Star Magazine never published a story documenting a laboratory test.

column1: “I don’t remember ever seeing any laboratory test that was done on Clinton’s DNA
column2: ” Bunton told WND.

column1: Bunton is now the owner of the Rivertown Magazine in Haverstraw
column2: New York.

column1: He affirmed to WND that the tabloid relied on the DNA evidence for Clinton published by independent counsel Kenneth Starr
column2: extracted from the infamous Monica Lewinsky blue dress.

column1: “We got a lot of phone calls from several people in the media
column2: including the New York Times
column3: wanting to know when we were going to get the DNA back
column4: ” Bunton recalled to WND. “We thought it was going to turn out to be his son
column5: but when the DNA came back there was no story there even to write.”

column1: The DNA test released by Kenneth Starr was the second of two DNA laboratory tests the FBI had run on Clinton
column2: but the public record leaves no doubt that Starr withheld the more robust test conducted by the FBI.

column1: ‘Twitter rules’
Many other figures who have challenged the Democratic Party or the left-leaning media narrative also have run into trouble with social media outlets
column2: including James O’Keefe and his Project Veritas
column3: which has exposed Clinton campaign voter fraud and agitation in a series of hidden-camera videos. Just as O’Keefe was preparing to release new revelations of voter fraud Oct. 13

column6: which prohibit: harassing other users
column7: threatening other users
column8: disclosing other users’ private information” or violating “other rules.” In a statement
column9: O’Keefe said he relies on social media to “bypass the media and directly reach the public.” On Monday
column10: O’Keefe wrote in a tweet Project Veritas was unable to upload its third video in the series to YouTube
column11: calling the apparent block “bizarre.” Earlier this month
column12: O’Keefe was forced to delete a tweet critical of a Hillary Clinton staffer to regain use of his account after it was suspended for a day. His account was suspended in the hours before a release of a new hidden-camera video that exposed a Clinton ally saying she could use executive action on guns
column13: the Daily Caller reported . Project Veritas posted an undercover video Oct. 17 proving Hillary Clinton supporters were inciting violence at Donald Trump rallies to gain negative media coverage. Millions of viewers watched the video in just a few hours
column14: but it didn’t show up on Google’s “trending” list on YouTube
column15: which Google owns
column16: noted SilenceisConsent.net . It did
column17: however
column18: trend on Twitter
column19: which Google does not own. Breitbart blogger Milo Yiannopoulos was suspended permanently by Twitter minutes before his “Gays for Trump” party at the Republican National Convention. For some 11 months
column20: the makers of the new movie “I’m Not Ashamed
column21: ” about the first victim of the Columbine killers in Colorado in 1999
column22: were unable to promote their movie through YouTube. The trailer was taken down late in 2015
column23: and the movie’s entire channel was suspended .
