column1: 12640;e142ad0523261508c8552ed5f61916e99da0489a;0;Matt Barber;2016-10-27T03:04:50.327+03:00;Why 'Never Trumpers' must reconsider;"While Democrats perpetually circle the wagons
column2: Republicans engage a perpetual circular firing squad. The same holds true for many evangelicals. Democrats and secularists count on it.

column1: And we never disappoint.
Full disclosure: I went from a dogged “Never Trumper” to a “Maybe Trumper” and
column2: finally
column3: settled as a “Reluctant Trumper.” I
column4: like any God-fearing father of daughters was
column5: and remain
column6: appalled by Donald Trump’s sordid past
column7: and his 11-year-old vulgar video in which he objectified women. His words are indefensible
column8: and I fully expect the Clinton camp to strategically release additional revolting and embarrassing opposition research about the Republican nominee before Election Day.

column1: Still
column2: I will be voting against Hillary Clinton on Nov. 8 in what is objectively and irrefutably the most effective way possible: by casting a vote
column3: for better or worse
column4: for the policies and promises of Donald Trump – and for the vice presidency of Gov. Mike Pence.

column1: Regrettably
column2: with many of my Never Trump friends I’m reminded of the fanatic who refuses his daughter chemotherapy and watches her die in an effort to convince himself (and others) of the strength of his own faith. Pride is an awful thing. We are to be “wise as serpents and innocent as doves” (Matthew 10:16). Foolishness called “faith” is just foolishness.

column1: Even so
column2: there are Christian Pharisees on both extremes of this Trump fiasco: first
column3: those Trumpian cultists who buy the “Make America great again!” pablum and deride any person who
column4: while not casting judgment upon others
column5: makes
column6: with all sincerity
column7: what they view as the principled decision. The latter say they’ll sit this one out (or go through the motions by voting third party – a wasted vote by any objective standard). While I appreciate this milder strain of Never Trumper’s sincerity
column8: I nonetheless believe it is sincerely wrong.

column1: And then there are the self-righteous
column2: plank-in-the-eye Never Trump prigs who slander as having “lost their saltiness
column3: ”“sinned against God” and “compromised their principles
column4: ” brothers and sisters who recognize the empirical reality that a vote for a horribly flawed (Lord knows I’m the worst sinner of all) baby Christian as president is a vote against Hillary Clinton’s tyranny in perpetuity.

column1: The Media Research Center has done America a tremendous service. In 2014 the watchdog organization released a video of an actual partial birth abortion – something Hillary Clinton stood on stage during the final presidential debate
column2: stared into the camera with cold
column3: callous eyes
column4: and then both lied about and defended unequivocally. I plead with Never Trumpers to watch the video and then prayerfully reassess their plans for Nov. 8.

column1: Mrs. Clinton’s beloved late-term abortion practice is one so brutal and needless that even the left-leaning American Medical Association has admitted that it is dangerous to the mother and never necessary under any circumstances
column2: not the least of which is for “the life or health of the mother.”

column1: During a partial-birth abortion
column2: the abortionist pulls a fully “viable” child – often kicking and thrashing – feet first from her mother’s womb
column3: leaving only the top of her head in the birth canal. This is so the abortionist can technically claim to be performing an abortion
column4: rather than committing murder.

column1: He then stabs the child through the base of her skull with scissors
column2: piercing her brain until her kicking and moving about suddenly and violently jerks to a halt. Next
column3: he opens the scissors to enlarge the wound as blood and brainstem fluid gush down his hands
column4: inserts a vacuum tube and sucks out her brains
column5: thereby collapsing her skull.

column1: Her now limp and lifeless body is then cast away like so much garbage.
This is homicide
column2: plain and simple. Hillary Clinton supports it. Donald Trump opposes it.

column1: We deserve God’s wrath and judgment as a nation for allowing this abortion holocaust to occur on our watch. In my estimation
column2: Mrs. Clinton is a bloodthirsty monster who enthusiastically supports this barbarity. Her Supreme Court appointees will ensure that tens of millions of precious babies like the one in the video are murdered in the same brutal manner.

column1: My conscience tells me that I must vote in such a way that exercising my civic duty will have the strongest net effect against Mrs. Clinton and ensure that she is stopped. She must not be elected president. To not vote – or to vote for a non-starter third party candidate
column2: which is effectively the same thing – while not an actual vote for Mrs. Clinton
column3: still puts this Mengele in a pantsuit one step closer to the White House and the Supreme Court.

column1: It’s simple math
column2: and it’s undeniable. The most effective thing you can personally do as a citizen is to vote against Mrs. Clinton by voting for Mr. Trump. This does the most electoral damage possible to candidate Clinton and offers the best chance for life that you can provide future generations.

column1: With its 1973 Roe v. Wade decision
column2: the U.S. Supreme Court put the government’s official stamp of approval on mass murder. Since then
column3: the battle lines have been drawn. This is war. “Pro-choicers” are the bad guys and pro-lifers
column4: the good guys. It really is that simple – that black and white. It’s good versus evil.

column1: History will reflect as much.
Under a President Hillary Clinton
column2: millions more babies will be tortured and dismembered alive. Under a President Donald Trump
column3: these millions might live. And yet
column4: even as Hillary sharpens her knives
column5: we quibble like fools over Donald’s potty mouth.

column1: The devil and Democrats: Oh
column2: how they love derision and division within the body of Christ.";english;2016-10-27T03:04:50.327+03:00;wnd.com;GB;1550.0;Why 'Never Trumpers' must reconsider;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 12642;8c3556b6a34cdf5fcc437e23e5c588e359532fe9;0;Michael Brown;2016-10-27T03:04:54.788+03:00;7 reasons I'll vote for Trump;"Print
Before you applaud me for my integrity or condemn me for selling out
column2: allow me to explain my decision to vote for Donald Trump on Nov. 8.

column1: First
column2: I’m writing this because I have been asked incessantly for months how I would be voting
column3: not because I think I’m someone special or that what I do should influence you.

column1: Second
column2: I’m not endorsing Donald Trump. In my mind
column3: there’s a world of difference between endorsing a candidate and voting for a candidate.

column1: Third
column2: I respect those in the #NeverTrump camp and share many of their concerns
column3: including the possibility of his further vulgarizing and degrading the nation
column4: the possibility of him deepening our ethnic and racial divides
column5: and the possibility of him alienating our allies and unnecessarily provoking our enemies
column6: just to name a few. Among the #NeverTrump voices I respect are columnists like David French and Ben Shapiro
column7: bloggers like Matt Walsh and evangelical leaders like Russell Moore and Beth Moore.

column1: Fourth
column2: I take strong exception to evangelicals who have fawned over Trump as if he were some kind of savior figure
column3: supporting him as if he were St. Donald. I also take issue with evangelical leaders who want us to minimize some of Trump’s failings
column4: constantly saying
column5: “Let him who is without sin cast the first one” (see John 8:7). This is not a question of condemning the man but rather a question of making a moral assessment as to his readiness to serve our nation.

column1: Fifth
column2: my decision to vote for Trump
column3: barring something earth-shattering between now and Nov. 8
column4: is consistent with my position
column5: which has been: 1) During the GOP primaries
column6: I issued strong warnings against voting for Trump while we had other excellent choices. I did this in writing
column7: on video and on the radio
column8: but always stating that if Trump won the nomination
column9: I would re-evaluate my position. 2) Once Trump became the Republican candidate
column10: I wrote that I was rooting for him to take steps in the right direction and thereby win my vote. 3) I have stated repeatedly that under no circumstances would I vote for Hillary. (For two strong warnings about Hillary
column11: see here and here .)

column1: So
column2: what has convinced me that I should now vote for Donald Trump?

column1: The culture war is not over! Gain hope
column2: courage and practical advice in Michael Brown’s latest book
column3: “Outlasting the Gay Revolution: Where Homosexual Activism Is Really Going and How to Turn the Tide”

column1: First
column2: I believe that he actually is serious about appointing pro-life
column3: pro-Constitution Supreme Court justices. When he said during the last debate that if you’re pro-life
column4: you want to see Roe v. Wade overturned
column5: and when he reiterated at his Gettysburg speech that he will be drawing from his list of 20 potential appointees
column6: he helped me feel more confident that he would not suddenly flip-flop if elected.

column1: Second
column2: one reason I endorsed Sen. Ted Cruz was because he took on the political establishment
column3: both Democratic and Republican
column4: to the point of calling it the Washington cartel. Trump is an absolute wrecking ball to the negative parts of the political system (although
column5: unfortunately
column6: he’s been a wrecking ball to some of the good parts of the system)
column7: so my vote for him is also a protest vote.

column1: Third
column2: I am voting for the Republican platform
column3: not the Republican Party
column4: which means I’m in agreement with the platform while at the same time having very little confidence in the party as a whole.

column1: Fourth
column2: while I have always felt that the line
column3: “We’re electing a president
column4: not a pastor
column5: ” was overstated and superficial
column6: if we rephrased it to say
column7: “We’re electing a general to train hand-to-hand combat warriors
column8: not a pastor
column9: ” it might have more relevance. In other words
column10: we are not looking for Trump to be a moral reformer (even if hedoes appoint righteous judges)
column11: and
column12: at this point
column13: he certainly is anything but a moral example (although we pray he will be truly converted and become one). Rather
column14: out of our choices for president
column15: which are stark
column16: we are voting for the one most likely to defeat Hillary and make some good decisions for the nation
column17: not be the savior. And with things so messed up in America
column18: the hand-to-hand combat analogy is closer to home.

column1: Fifth
column2: within the first few minutes of the last debate
column3: the massive differences between Hillary and Trump were there for the world to see
column4: she a pro-abortion radical and an extreme supporter of the LGBT agenda and he unashamedly speaking out against late-term abortions and wanting to appoint justices who would defend our essential liberties. Since I have the opportunity to vote
column5: I feel that I should vote for Trump.

column1: Sixth
column2: Trump continues to be drawn to conservative Christians
column3: and not just ones who tickle his ears. One of my dear friends has spent hours with Trump and members of his family
column4: and he has told me that in 55 years of ministry
column5: no one has received him as openly and graciously as has Trump. Yet my friend continues to speak the truth to him in the clearest possible terms. While I am not one of those claiming that Trump is a born-again Christian (I see absolutely no evidence of this)
column6: the fact that he continues to listen to godly men and open the door to their counsel indicates that something positive could possibly be going on. It also indicates that these godly leaders might be a positive influence on him if he were elected president.

column1: Seventh
column2: although I’m quite aware that a president could do great harm or good to the nation
column3: I’m far more concerned with what we as God’s people do with our own lives and witnesses
column4: and for me
column5: the state of the church of America is much more important than the state of the White House. In that context
column6: I echo the words (and warning) of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.: “The church must be reminded that it is not the master or the servant of the state
column7: but rather the conscience of the state. It must be the guide and the critic of the state
column8: and never its tool. If the church does not recapture its prophetic zeal
column9: it will become an irrelevant social club without moral or spiritual authority.”

column1: So
column2: in sum: 1) My hope is in God
column3: not Donald Trump
column4: and I do recognize that either Hillary or Trump has the potential to do great harm to America; 2) My urgent call is for us as followers of Jesus to get our own act together so we can be the salt and light of the nation; 3) I will continue to urge all believers not to vote for Hillary Clinton
column5: whose policies will certainly do us great harm; and 4) Ultimately
column6: the most effective way to defeat Hillary is to vote for Trump
column7: while also praying that God will use him for good
column8: not for evil.

column1: In the end
column2: if Trump gets elected and fails miserably
column3: I will be grieved but not devastated. If he does well
column4: I will rejoice.

column1: Either way
column2: though
column3: my vote is just that: a vote. My greater role is to live a life pleasing to God with the hope of advancing a gospel-based moral and cultural revolution. Receive Michael Brown's commentaries in your email BONUS: By signing up for Michael Brown's alerts
column4: you will also be signed up for news and special offers from WND via email. Name *";english;2016-10-27T03:04:54.788+03:00;wnd.com;GB;1550.0;7 reasons I'll vote for Trump;0.0;;0;1;0;0;0;bias

column1: 12651;d71e22efbde8ecd594c5444be2b252f9f7d83f82;0;Leo Hohmann;2016-10-27T03:32:35.039+03:00;26 WikiLeaks bombshells on Hillary you need to know;"26 WikiLeaks bombshells on Hillary you need to know Most explosive revelations that could keep Clinton out of White House Published: 26 mins ago About | | Archive Leo Hohmann is a news editor for WND. He has been a reporter and editor at several suburban newspapers in the Atlanta and Charlotte
column2: North Carolina
column3: areas and also served as managing editor of Triangle Business Journal in Raleigh
column4: North Carolina. Print Hillary Clinton with top aide Huma Abedin.

column1: WikiLeaks has provided a treasure trove of inside information on what Hillary Clinton really thinks about important issues such as trade and immigration
column2: but Clinton herself has chosen not to answer questions about the revelations.

column1: She has focused instead on criticizing the Russians as the source of the hacks
column2: despite the fact there is no proof of Russian involvement.

column1: The emails also shed light on how the Clinton campaign interacts with Wall Street banks
column2: with friendly media
column3: and how it worked to undermine the candidacy of Democratic rival Bernie Sanders with the help of the DNC.

column1: WikiLeaks says it has about 50
column2: 000 emails from the private Gmail account of John Podesta
column3: a senior Democratic Party official who has served as White House chief of staff under President Bill Clinton and a senior adviser to President Obama. He was the author of Obama’s climate change policy. John Podesta

column1: In February Podesta moved seamlessly from the White House to become chairman of Hillary Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign.
Here are some of the most explosive revelations from the WikiLeaks email dumps featuring Podesta’s account and others.
Preference for Muslim Americans In 2008
column2: when Podesta served as co-chair of President-elect Barack Obama’s transition team
column3: Michael Froman
column4: a former Citibank executive
column5: sent Podesta a “list of African American
column6: Latino and Asian American candidates
column7: broken down by Cabinet/Deputy and Under/Assistant/Deputy Assistant level
column8: plus a list of Native American
column9: Arab/Muslim American and Disabled American candidates.” The Arab American list came with a special note to exclude Arab Christians – they had to be both Arab and Muslim.As New Republic reports
column10: Obama’s eventual cabinet appointments ended up almost entirely as Froman recommended.Froman ultimately became the recipient of the largest bailout from the federal government during the financial crisis.

column1: Shielding Obama In a March 4
column3: email to Hillary Clinton’s lawyer Cheryl Mills
column4: Clinton’s eventual campaign chairman Podesta asks if they should withhold email exchanges between Clinton and President Obama that were sent over Clinton’s private server.The day before Podesta sent his email to Mills
column5: the House Benghazi Committee privately told Clinton to preserve and hand over all her emails.The email from Podesta to Mills says: “Think we should hold emails to and from potus? That’s the heart of his exec privilege. We could get them to ask for that. They may not care
column6: but I(t) seems like they will.” An email exchange between Podesta
column7: Paul Begala
column8: and Clinton pollster GQRR shows the Clinton campaign was pushing the Muslim Obama narrative back in January 2008. Included was a survey of Obama “negative facts” such as this one: “Obama (owe-BAHM-uh)’s father was a Muslim and Obama grew up among Muslims in the world’s most populous Islamic country.” The pollster writes “we have reworked the Obama message into the survey
column9: as requested.”

column1: Secret speeches to Wall Street Hillary Clinton was so enraged that Bill Clinton was forced to cancel a paid speech at Wall Street bank Morgan Stanley in 2015 that she “needed a cool down period.” The email chain
column2: on March 11
column4: before she formally launched her campaign
column5: includes top aides to both Hillary Clinton and former President Clinton
column6: and reveals that Hillary’s future campaign aides were concerned about the political impact of Bill giving a speech to a Wall Street bank. “Morgan Stanley is coming down
column7: ” wrote Robby Mook in an email to top Clinton aides.Top aide Huma Abedin explained that Hillary would not be happy about it
column8: writing: “HRC very strongly did not want him to cancel that particular speech. I will have to tell her that [Bill] chose to cancel it
column9: not that we asked.” Hillary Clinton’s paid speeches to Goldman Sachs and other financial firms
column10: a point of contention during this year’s primary
column11: were the subject of an email to Podesta. Excerpts from some of the speeches had been flagged by Clinton’s research team
column12: including the necessity of having “both a public and a private position” on issues. It was just part of “making sausage” in the political arena
column13: she said
column14: that certain positions on issues needed to be kept hidden from the public. Some “flags” in Hillary Clinton’s paid speeches were noted in a Jan. 25 email from campaign research director Tony Carrk to top Clinton advisers
column15: including Clinton’s declaration that “My dream is a hemispheric common market
column16: with open trade and open borders
column17: some time in the future with energy that is as green and sustainable as we can get it
column18: powering growth and opportunity for every person in the hemisphere.” Countless establishment media outlets parlaying themselves as “fact checkers” tried to downplay this email by saying it was “mostly about trade
column19: ” not immigration
column20: as if the words “open borders” were never mentioned. But the email exchange also shows how Hillary’s about-face on the TPP trade deal was mere pandering to Bernie Sanders’ voters and had no basis in reality in terms of how she really feels about trade deals. In a speech at Goldman-Black Rock on Feb. 4
column23: Clinton admitted she’s “Kind Of Far Removed” from middle-class struggles due to “The Economic
column25: Fortunes That My Husband And I Now Enjoy.” Clinton
column27: boasted of her ties to Wall Street
column28: an issue primary opponent Bernie Sanders continually raised. Clinton still has refused to release transcripts of her paid speeches while blasting Donald Trump for not releasing his tax returns.

column1: Working in tandem with ‘friendly’ media WND reported Tuesday emails showing reporters
column2: editors and contributors not just advocating for Hillary Clinton but apparently colluding with the campaign. Univision Chairman Haim Saban urged the Clinton campaign to hit Donald Trump harder over immigration. The Boston Globe tried to time a Clinton opinion piece to do the most good in New Hampshire. CNBC’s John Harwood urged Clinton campaign chairman Podesta to watch out for then-GOP candidate Dr. Ben Carson. Democratic National Committee official and CNN contributor Donna Brazile apparently tipped off the Clinton campaign to a potentially difficult CNN town-hall question on capital punishment during the Democratic Party primary season. Brazile adamantly denies it . In a July 2015 email
column3: New York Times reporter Mark Leibovich appeared to ask permission from Hillary Clinton’s communications director
column4: Jennifer Palmieri
column5: to use certain quotes of the presidential candidate in an article. Palmieri replied
column6: suggesting he remove a reference Clinton made to Sarah Palin and delete Clinton’s statement
column7: “And gay rights has moved much faster than women’s rights or civil rights
column8: which is an interesting phenomenon.” CNBC correspondent John Harwood
column9: who was widely criticized for posing biased questions to Donald Trump as a primary debate moderator
column10: effectively served as an adviser to the Clinton campaign
column11: emailing Podesta with the subject line “Watch out.” The warning was regarding GOP presidential candidate Ben Carson
column12: who “could give you real trouble in a general (election).” Maggie Haberman
column13: a former Politico reporter who now works for the New York Times
column14: was described in a January 2015 memo as having “a very good relationship” with the Clinton campaign. “We have had her tee up stories for us before and have never been disappointed
column15: ” the memo said.

column1: Demeaning Catholics Podesta discussed fomenting “revolution” in the Catholic Church with a progressive activist while Hillary’s now-communications director Jennifer Palmieri mocked Catholics who speak out against the liberal social causes of the Democratic Party. “There needs to be a Catholic Spring
column2: in which Catholics themselves demand the end of a middle ages dictatorship and the beginning of a little democracy and respect for gender equality in the Catholic Church
column3: ” Sandy Newman
column4: president and founder of the nonprofit Voices for Progress
column5: wrote Podesta in February 2012 . The email
column6: among the third batch released by WikiLeaks
column7: was titled “opening for a Catholic Spring? just musing.” Podesta tells Newman of progressive organizations he and his colleagues created to recruit members of the church who can lead a revolution when the time is right.“We created Catholics in Alliance for the Common Good to organize for a moment like this
column8: ” the Clinton campaign chairman writes. “But I think it lacks the leadership to do so now. Likewise Catholics United. Like most Spring movements
column9: I think this one will have to be bottom up.” Clinton
column10: who has accused Trump of praising Putin
column11: called the Russian leader in a 2014 speech “engaging” and “a very interesting conversationalist.” Excerpts from Clinton’s speeches were contained in a document emailed to Podesta to point out quotes that could harm the campaign.

column1: Collusion with DOJ Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon alerted staffers that the Justice Department was proposing to publish Clinton’s work-related emails
column2: contending it showed collusion between the Obama administration and Clinton’s campaign. Fallon wrote that “DOJ folks” told him a court hearing in the case had been planned. The day after Hillary Clinton testified in front of the House Select Committee on Benghazi last October
column3: Podesta met for dinner with a small group of well-connected friends
column4: including Peter Kadzik
column5: a top official at the Justice Department. Lawyers also told the Clinton campaign in emails that Hillary’s private email scandal “ smacks of acting above the law and it smacks of the type of thing I’ve either gotten discovery sanctions for
column6: fired people for
column7: etc .”

column1: Entanglements with foreign governments King Muhammad IV of Morocco made a $12 million pledge to fund the Clinton Global Initiative conference
column2: but only if the likely presidential candidate attended the event as a speaker. Hillary’s top aide
column3: Huma Abedin
column4: wrote in a January 2015 email that “if HRC was not part of it
column5: meeting was a non-starter.” Then she warned: “She created this mess and she knows it.” Hillary ended up not attending but her husband Bill did. An email from Hillary Clinton’s account to Podesta on Aug. 17
